title: Swindler v. Swindler
description: This case involves whether article 3 of the South Carolina Uniform Commercial Code applies to a note secured by a mortgage in real estate.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
      James R. Swindler, Marshalene S.
      Frady,
      and Rebecca Spears,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
      Nancy W. Swindler
      and Commercial Credit Corporation,       
      Defendants,
Of whom Nancy W. Swindler is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 3658
Heard March 11, 2003 â€“ Filed July 7, 
  2003

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
David Randolph Whitt, Henry Guyton Murrel, and Pearce W. Fleming, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondents.
Howard S. Sheftman and J. Alton Bivens, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  In this foreclosure action, 
  we are asked to determine whether a promissory note secured by a real estate 
  mortgage is a negotiable instrument governed by Article 3 of the South Carolina 
  Uniform Commercial Code (â€œUCCâ€).Â  James R. Swindler, Marshalene S. Frady, and 
  Rebecca Spears (collectively, â€œthe Swindler Familyâ€) brought this action against 
  their sister-in-law, Nancy Swindler (â€œNancyâ€), to foreclose a mortgage encumbering 
  a 54.5-acre tract of land Nancy purchased from their mother, Margaret Swindler 
  (â€œMargaretâ€).Â  Nancy asserted various defenses, including that Margaret had 
  renounced the underlying debt by giving Nancy possession of the original Note.Â  
  The master-in-equity concluded Article 3 of the UCC did not govern the transaction, 
  and therefore, the defense of renunciation under South Carolina Code Annotated 
  section 36-3-605(1) (1976) [1]  
  was not applicable.Â  The master entered a judgment of foreclosure and sale in 
  favor of the Swindler Family.Â  Nancy appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Margaret had four children â€“ the three Respondents 
  to whom we refer as the Swindler Family and a son, Timothy.Â  Timothy was married 
  to Nancy.Â  During Timothyâ€™s lifetime, Margaret conveyed a 54.5-acre tract of 
  land to Nancy to be Nancy and Timothyâ€™s residence.Â  In return, Nancy executed 
  a note, agreeing to pay Margaret $200,000.00 for the property.Â  The Note was 
  secured by a mortgage covering the property.
After both Margaret and Timothy died, James Swindler 
  attempted to transfer a one-quarter interest in the Note and Mortgage to each 
  member of the Swindler Family in his capacity as personal representative of 
  Margaretâ€™s estate.Â  The Swindler Family then demanded payment of $150,000.00 
  from Nancy, representing three-quarters of the amount due on the Note, and brought 
  this foreclosure action.
Nancy asserted as a defense that Margaret had renounced 
  the debt by delivering the original Note to her.Â  In support of her position, 
  Nancy cited section 36-3-605(1), which states in applicable part: â€œThe holder 
  of an instrument may even without consideration discharge any party . . . (b) 
  by renouncing his rights . . . by surrender of the instrument to be discharged.â€ 
  (Emphasis added).Â  During the trial, only Nancy testified and presented witnesses.Â  
  Nancy established the Note and Mortgage had been sent to Margaret before execution, 
  and Margaret delivered the original Note and Mortgage to Nancy and Timothy before 
  her death.Â  The Swindler Family admitted Nancy has possession of the original 
  Note and Mortgage.
The master declined to apply section 36-3-605.Â  He 
  construed South Carolina Code Annotated section 36-3-103(2) (1976), [2]  governing negotiable instruments under Article 
  3, to superimpose the limitations of Article 9 onto Article 3.Â  Because Article 
  9 of the UCC, specifically South Carolina Code Annotated section 36-9-104(j) 
  (Supp. 2000), excludes from its application â€œthe creation or transfer of an 
  interest in or lien on real estate[,]â€ the master ruled Article 3 did not apply 
  to notes secured by mortgages on real estate.Â  He also found no evidence existed 
  to prove how Nancy obtained the original Note and Mortgage or to establish Margaret 
  intended Nancyâ€™s obligation to be discharged.Â  Therefore, he ruled the Swindler 
  Family was a proper holder of the Note and $150,000.00 was due.Â  The master 
  entered a judgment of foreclosure and sale in favor of the Swindler Family.Â  
  Nancy filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment, which the master denied.Â  
  Nancy appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to foreclose a real estate mortgage 
  is an action in equity.â€Â  BB&T of South Carolina v. Kidwell, 350 
  S.C. 382, 387, 565 S.E.2d 316, 319 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  On appeal from an action 
  in equity, this Court may â€œfind facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 
  81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Furthermore, this Court is not bound by 
  the trial courtâ€™s legal determinations.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 
  338 S.C. 406, 411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 718-19 (2000).
DISCUSSION
Among the issues raised on appeal, Nancy asserts 
  the master erred by ruling Article 3 of the UCC does not govern a note secured 
  by a mortgage on real property.Â  Furthermore, pursuant to section 36-3-605(1), 
  Nancy argues a presumption arose that Margaret renounced the debt because Margaret 
  delivered the Note to Nancy prior to her death, and the Swindler family failed 
  to present any evidence to overcome the presumption.Â  We agree with both assertions 
  and reverse the masterâ€™s order.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Applicability of Article 3
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno 
  Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003).Â  Moreover, 
  â€œ[w]here the terms of the statute are clear, [this Court] must apply those terms 
  according to their literal meaning.â€Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & 
  Envtl Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002); see also 
  Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 369, 468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996) (holding 
  when â€œinterpreting a statute, words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning 
  without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s 
  operationâ€).
Article 3 applies to negotiable instruments.Â  Thus, 
  as an initial matter, we must determine whether the Note is a negotiable instrument 
  and a â€œnoteâ€ as defined by Article 3 of the UCC.Â  If not, then Article 3 would 
  clearly not apply and our inquiry would end.
South Carolina Code Annotated section 36-3-104 
  (1976) provides:

  (1)   Any writing to be a negotiable instrument within this chapter 
  must
  
  (a)  be signed by the maker or drawer; and
  (b) contain an unconditional promise or order to pay a sum certain in money 
  and no other promise, order, obligation or power given by the maker or drawer 
  except as authorized by this chapter; and
  (c)  be payable on demand or at a definite time; and
  (d) be payable to order or to bearer.
  
  (2)   A writing which complies with the requirements of this section 
  is

.Â Â Â Â  .Â Â Â Â  .

  
  (d) a â€œnoteâ€ if it is a promise other than a certificate of deposit.
  

Clearly each of these requirements is met in this 
  case.Â  Furthermore, neither party asserts the instrument fails to satisfy the 
  above criteria.
Having determined the Note is a negotiable instrument 
  and a â€œnote,â€ we next consider the masterâ€™s conclusion Article 3 does not apply 
  to a note secured by a real estate mortgage.Â  In this regard, it appears the 
  master misread section 36-3-103(2).Â  This section states â€œ[t]he provisions of 
  this chapter are subject to the provisions of the chapter on . . . secured transactions 
  [(Article 9)].â€Â  The master construed this statute to act as a limitation on 
  the application of Article 3 so as to exclude from coverage a note secured by 
  a real estate mortgage.Â  He bolstered his decision by noting â€œthe existence 
  of S.C. Code Â§ 29-3-330, which expressly provides methods for satisfying a mortgage 
  of real estate.â€
We conclude the master erred.Â  No provision in 
  Article 3 exists which distinguishes an unsecured note from a note secured by 
  a real estate mortgage.Â  Moreover, no provision in Article 9 excludes a note 
  secured by a real estate mortgage from the application of Article 3.Â  The negotiability 
  of a note is not altered by the execution of a related real estate mortgage.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-3-119(2) (1976) (stating a note remains subject 
  to the terms of Article 3 irrespective of the occurrence of any other transaction); 
  cf. Intâ€™l Minerals & Chem. Corp. v. Matthews, 321 S.E.2d 545, 
  547 (N.C. Ct. App. 1984) (holding â€œincorporating into a note the liens that 
  secure its paymentâ€ does not affect the applicability of Article 3).
The Official Comment to section 36-3-119(2) states:

5.Â  Subsection (2) rejects decisions which have carried the 
  rule that contemporaneous writings must be read together to the length of holding 
  that a clause in a mortgage affecting a note destroyed the negotiability of 
  the note.Â  The negotiability of an instrument is always to be determined by 
  what appears on the face of the instrument alone . . . .Â  [If the note] 
  merely refers to a separate agreement or states that it arises out of such an 
  agreement, it is negotiable.

(Emphasis added).Â  Furthermore, any â€œcontemporaneous 
  writing[,] e.g., a chattel mortgage given to secure a negotiable note[,] 
  is not read into the note to destroy its negotiability.â€Â  Id. reporterâ€™s 
  cmt (emphasis added); cf. Burch v. Ashburn, 295 S.C. 274, 278, 
  368 S.E.2d 82, 84 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œ[T]he contemporaneous execution of the two 
  writings does not affect the note, which is enforceable according to its tenor 
  without regard to any breach of theâ€ other agreement.).Â Â  Thus, even when executed 
  simultaneously with a mortgage, a note remains subject to the provisions of 
  Article 3.Â  See Northwestern Bank v. Neal, 271 S.C. 544, 546-47, 
  248 S.E.2d 585, 586 (1978).
Furthermore, we do not agree with the masterâ€™s 
  construction of sections 36‑3‑103(2) and 36-9-104(j).Â  We conclude 
  these provisions are unambiguous and clearly state Article 3 governs a note 
  even when secured by a mortgage on real property.
First, the master misquoted section 36-3-103(2) 
  to state Article 3 was subject to the â€œlimitationsâ€ of Article 9.Â  However, 
  this section states â€œ[t]he provisions of this chapter are subject to the provisions 
  of the chapter on . . . secured transactions [Article 9]â€ not â€œlimitations of 
  Article 9â€ as stated in the masterâ€™s order.Â  (Emphasis added).Â  Article 9 provides 
  it does not apply â€œto the creation or transfer of an interest in or lien on 
  real estate.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-9-104(j).Â  However, nothing in Article 9 
  provides a limitation on the applicability of Article 3 to notes secured by 
  mortgages on real estate.
Moreover, the Official Comment to section 36-3-103 
  explains the interaction between Articles 3 and 9.

2.Â  Instruments which fall within the scope of this Article 
  may also be subject to other Articles of the [UCC].Â  Many items in the course 
  of bank collection will of course be negotiable instruments, and the same may 
  be true of collateral pledged as security for a debt.Â  In such cases this Article, 
  which is general, is, in case of conflicting provisions, subject to the 
  Article[] which deal[s] specifically with the type of transaction or instrument 
  involved: . . . Article 9 (Secured Transactions).Â  In the case of a negotiable 
  instrument which is subject to . . . Article 9 because it is collateral, 
  the provisions of [Article 3] continue to be applicable except insofar as 
  there may be conflicting provisions . . . .

(Emphasis added).
Reading sections 36-3-103(2) and 36-9-104(j) in conjunction, 
  especially in light of the Official Comment to section 36-3-103, we conclude 
  Article 3 controls the Note.Â  This interpretation reflects the clear intent 
  of the UCC; Article 9 controls over Article 3 only where some conflict between 
  the applicable provisions of Articles 3 and 9 exists.Â  Here, no conflict exists 
  because Article 9 does not address the underlying indebtedness of a security 
  interest.Â  See Midfirst Bank, SSB v. C.W. Haynes & Co., Inc., 
  893 F.Supp. 1304, 1312-13 (D.S.C. 1994) (interpreting South Carolina law, holding 
  the inapplicability of Article 9 to a negotiable instrument does not affect 
  the application of Article 3); First Valley Bank v. First Sav. & Loan 
  Assâ€™n of Cent. Indiana, 412 N.E.2d 1237, 1240-41 (Ind. Ct. App. 1980) (rejecting 
  the argument â€œthat mortgage notes, which are secured by liens on real estate, 
  lie entirely outside the coverage of the [UCC]â€ and adopting the view that Article 
  3 applies â€œto promissory notes secured by mortgagesâ€).
We also conclude the masterâ€™s reliance on South 
  Carolina Code Annotated section 29-3-330 (1991), governing the satisfaction 
  of real estate mortgages, is misplaced.Â  In his order, the master noted section 
  29‑3‑330 requires written satisfaction of a mortgage.Â  The master 
  found this language supported his ruling that renunciation of the debt under 
  Article 3 of the UCC was not intended by our Legislature to apply to a note 
  secured by a real estate mortgage.
South Carolina Code Annotated section 29-3-310 
  (Supp. 2000) states a mortgagee â€œwho has received . . . satisfaction . . 
  . of his debts . . . secured by a mortgage on real estate shall . . . enter 
  satisfaction . . . on the mortgage.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  This section clearly 
  contemplates the satisfaction of a debt, the note, and the satisfaction of the 
  security interest for that debt, the mortgage, as separate actions.Â  Pursuant 
  to this section, the debtor must first satisfy the note, and then the mortgagee 
  must enter satisfaction of the mortgage.Â  Thus, the masterâ€™s conclusion that 
  section 29-3-330 supports his ruling with respect to Articles 3 and 9 is incorrect.
In this case, when Nancy made the Note, she executed 
  a document subject to the provisions of Article 3, not Article 9.Â  Her subsequent 
  or simultaneous creation of the Mortgage did nothing to change the nature of 
  the Note itself.Â  Thus, the Note remained subject to the provisions of Article 
  3.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Renunciation of Note
Having determined the Note is a negotiable instrument 
  governed by Article 3 of the UCC, we next address Nancyâ€™s argument that Margaret 
  renounced the debt by giving Nancy possession of the original Note.Â  We find 
  Nancyâ€™s possession of the original Note gave rise to the presumption that Margaret 
  renounced the debt prior to her death.Â  Moreover, the Swindler Family failed 
  to produce any evidence to rebut this presumption.Â  Thus, we conclude Nancyâ€™s 
  debt was discharged.
As noted above, section 36-3-605(1) provides: â€œThe 
  holder of an instrument may even without consideration discharge any party . 
  . . (b) by renouncing his rights . . . by surrender of the instrument to 
  be discharged.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  â€œWhen the obligor has possession [of 
  the instrument], the party suing on the instrument has to overcome a presumption 
  that the instrument was discharged.â€Â  2 James J. White & Robert S. 
  Summer, Uniform Commercial Code Â§ 16-13 at 134-35 (4th ed. 1995) (emphasis 
  added); see also Winkel v. Erpelding, 526 N.W.2d 316, 319 (Iowa 
  1995) (â€œThe debtorâ€™s possession of the instrument creates a rebuttable presumption 
  of discharge.â€); Columbia Sav. v. Zelinger, 794 P.2d 231, 234 (Colo. 
  1990) (â€œPossession of the instrument by the debtor . . . is normally sufficient 
  to create a rebuttable presumption of discharge.â€).Â  Therefore, only if the 
  obligee can show the obligor is in possession of the instrument â€œâ€˜unintentionally, 
  or under a mistake, or without [] authorityâ€™â€ can the presumption be overcome 
  and the discharge proven to be without effect.Â  Peoples Bank of S.C. v. Robinson, 
  272 S.C. 155, 158, 249 S.E.2d 784, 785 (1978) (quoting 11 Am. Jur. 2d Bills 
  & Notes Â§ 906 (1964)).
At trial, Nancy testified that prior to Margaretâ€™s 
  death, Margaret delivered the original Note to her.Â  Further, Nancy testified 
  that she was never informed her possession of the Note was by mistake or that 
  she had the Note without authority.Â  Moreover, the Swindler Family admitted 
  Nancy has possession of the original Note and provided no evidence or testimony 
  to indicate Margaret made a mistake by delivering the Note to Nancy or did not 
  intend for Nancy to be discharged from her obligation.
Therefore, we conclude Nancyâ€™s testimony is sufficient 
  to create the presumption Margaret intended to discharge Nancy from her obligations 
  under the Note.Â  Because the Swindler Family did not produce any evidence or 
  argument to the contrary, they have failed to rebut this presumption.Â  Thus, 
  we conclude Nancyâ€™s original obligation to pay $200,000.00 for the 54.5-acret 
  tract of land is discharged.
CONCLUSION [3] 
For the foregoing reasons, the masterâ€™s order finding 
  Article 3 of the UCC inapplicable to a note secured by a mortgage on real property 
  and ruling Margaret did not renounce her rights in the Note by surrendering 
  it to Nancy is reversed and this case is remanded with instructions to enter 
  satisfaction of the mortgage in accordance with section 29-3-310.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
CURETON and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Much of the statutory authority governing notes and security interests 
    has been amended since the inception of this litigation.Â  However, in deciding 
    this case we must apply â€œthe law in effect at the time the cause of action 
    accrued [because it] controls the partiesâ€™ legal relationships and rights.â€Â  
    Stephens v. Draffin, 327 S.C. 1, 5, 488 S.E.2d 307, 309 (1997).

 
   
    [2]  Section 36-3-103 (2) provides: â€œThe provisions of this chapter are 
    subject to the provisions of the chapter on bank deposits and collections 
    (Chapter 4) and secured transactions (Chapter 9).â€

 
    [3]
   
      Because of our holdings with respect to the applicability of Article 
    3, and the Noteâ€™s renunciation, we need not address Nancyâ€™s other issues on 
    appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The
        State,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Paul Thompson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3659
Submitted April 18, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  July 7, 2003

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Â  Paul Thompson was tried 
  in absentia and without counsel.Â  He was convicted of discharging 
  a firearm into a dwelling and malicious injury to personal property over $1000 
  but less than $5000.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to five years on each count 
  to run concurrently.Â  We reverse and remand. 
  [1] 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Vanessa Pearson was at home with her adult daughter, 
  Najwa, on October 30, 1999 when a man named Derrick came to her door and asked 
  for â€œJunior.â€Â  Pearson told him that no one by the name of â€œJuniorâ€ lived there.Â  
  Thirty minutes later he came to her door again and asked for â€œJunior.â€Â  She 
  reiterated to him that no one by the name of â€œJuniorâ€ lived there.Â  Pearson 
  testified that Derrick, Paul Thompson, and Michael Graham then started shooting 
  at her car and into her house.Â  The damage to her car was about $4000.Â  Pearson 
  identified Peggy Wright as sitting in the backseat of the vehicle that the men 
  drove during the occurrence.
Graham, Wright, and Thompson were tried together 
  for discharging a firearm into a dwelling and malicious injury to personal property 
  over $1000 but less than $5000.Â  The same counsel represented Graham and Wright.Â  
  Thompson was not present nor did he have counsel present.Â  The judge told the 
  bailiff to call Thompsonâ€™s name three times at the courthouse door before the 
  jury selection began.Â  After Thompson did not respond, he was tried in his absence.Â  
  Graham and Wright presented alibi evidence, which resulted in their acquittals.Â  
  Thompson was found guilty as charged.
A sealed sentence was given as required by law.Â  
  The sealed sentence is NOT opened until the defendant is arrested and 
  before the court.Â  After his arrest, Thompson was brought before the court for 
  the opening of the sealed sentences.Â  Pursuant to State v. Smith, 276 
  S.C. 494, 280 S.E.2d 200 (1981), the circuit judge opening the sealed sentence 
  is under the law the sentencing judge.Â  Exercising his discretion, the judge 
  sentenced Thompson to five years on each count, concurrently.
At sentencing, Thompsonâ€™s attorney professed that 
  Thompson appeared at four or five roll calls after his arrest on November 15, 
  1999.Â  During that time, Thompson requested through the Clerk of Court representation 
  from the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Thompson contends he was told he did not 
  meet the cut-off amount of money to qualify for a public defender.Â  He explained 
  to them that he had child support arrearage payments that virtually consumed 
  his salary and offered to produce documentation.Â  According to Thompsonâ€™s attorney, 
  no one would listen to him regarding his child support payments.Â  The court 
  refuted Thompsonâ€™s assertion, explicating that if Thompson had said he did not 
  have an attorney, one would have been appointed for him.
A Bench Warrant was issued for Thompson on September 
  11, 2000 and another was issued on May 17, 2001.Â  During September 2001, Thompson 
  went to a rehabilitation facility in Maryland for cocaine and alcohol addiction.Â  
  He left the facility on November 19, 2001.Â  He went to High Point, North Carolina 
  and then to his uncleâ€™s house in Bennettsville.Â  Thompson was tried on November 
  28, 2001.Â  Thompsonâ€™s brother testified that the family was only given fourteen 
  hours notice of trial.
The judge determined that a lawyer would have been 
  appointed for him if he had presented himself at trial:

THE COURT:Â Â Â Â Â  Well, I can say here for the record if he 
  would have been here like the other two defendants were, didnâ€™t have a lawyer, 
  we would have appointed one for him.
[THOMPSONâ€™S COUNSEL]:Â  Yes, sir, Your Honor.
THE COURT:Â  But you canâ€™t appoint one for him if he runs and 
  doesnâ€™t even come to court.

LAW/ANALYSIS
Thompson argues the judge erred in denying his 
  motion for a new trial because he was denied the right to counsel at trial.
I.Â  RIGHT TO COUNSEL
It is well established that a defendant may be 
  tried in his absence.Â  Rule 16, SCRCrimP (â€œExcept in cases wherein capital punishment 
  is a permissible sentence, a person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies 
  may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his absence 
  upon a finding by the court that such person has received notice of his right 
  to be present and that a warning was given that the trial would proceed in his 
  absence upon a failure to attend the court.â€). 
  [2] Â  However, to try a defendant without counsel is a completely different 
  matter.Â  Pennsylvania v. Ford, 715 A.2d 1141, 1143 (1998) (citing Gideon 
  v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335, 83 S.Ct. 792, 9 L.Ed.2d 799 (1963)).
â€œThe Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments of our Constitution 
  guarantee that a person brought to trial in any state or federal court must 
  be afforded the right to the assistance of counsel before he can be validly 
  convicted and punished by imprisonment.â€ Â Faretta v. California, 422 
  U.S. 806, 807, 95 S.Ct. 2525, 2527, 45 L.Ed.2d 562, 566 (1975); accord 
  Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335, 339-40, 83 S.Ct. 792, 794, 9 L.Ed.2d 
  799, 802-03 (1963).Â  Moreover, an indigent criminal defendant may request the 
  court to appoint an attorney to represent him.Â  Gideon, 372 U.S. at 344, 
  83 S.Ct. at 796-97, 9 L.Ed.2d at 802; see Scott v. Illinois, 440 
  U.S. 367, 367, 99 S.Ct. 1158, 1159, 59 L.Ed.2d 383, 389 (1979) (â€œThe Sixth and 
  Fourteenth Amendments require that no indigent criminal defendant be sentenced 
  to a term of imprisonment unless the State has afforded him the right to assistance 
  of appointed counsel in his defense . . .â€).
â€œOf all the rights that an accused person has, 
  the right to be represented by counsel is by far the most pervasive for it affects 
  his ability to assert any other rights he may have.â€Â  United States v. Cronic, 
  466 U.S. 648, 654, 104 S.Ct. 2039, 2044, 80 L.Ed.2d 657, 664 (1984).Â  The erroneous 
  deprivation of a defendantâ€™s fundamental right to the assistance of counsel 
  is per se reversible error.Â  State v. Boykin, 324 S.C. 
  552, 555, 478 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 1996) (citing Chapman v. California, 
  386 U.S. 18, 23 n.8, 87 S.Ct. 824, 828 n.8, 17 L.Ed.2d 705 (1967)).Â  â€œActual 
  or constructive denial of the assistance of counsel altogether is legally presumed 
  to result in prejudice.â€Â  McKnight v. State, 320 S.C. 356, 358, 465 S.E.2d 
  352, 353 (1995) (quoting Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 692, 
  104 S.Ct. 2052, 2067, 80 L.Ed.2d 674, 696 (1984)).
  II.               
  RELINQUISHMENT OF RIGHT TO COUNSEL
A defendant may surrender his right to counsel 
  through (1) waiver by affirmative, verbal request; (2) waiver by conduct; and 
  (3) forfeiture. Â State v. Boykin, 324 S.C. 552, 556, 478 S.E.2d 689, 
  690 (Ct. App. 1996).
  A.              
Waiver 
   
A defendant may waive his Sixth Amendment right 
  to counsel.Â  A waiver is an intentional and voluntary relinquishment of a known 
  right.Â  United States v. Goldberg, 67 F.3d 1092, 1099 (3d Cir. 1995); 
  Maxwell v. Genez, 350 S.C. 563, 571, 567 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  The courts indulge every reasonable presumption against waiver of fundamental 
  constitutional rights, and do not presume acquiescence in the loss of fundamental 
  rights.Â  Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458, 464, 58 S.Ct. 1019, 1023, 82 
  L.Ed. 1461, 1466 (1938); Pitts v. North Carolina, 395 F.2d 182, 188 (4th 
  Cir. 1968).
1. Waiver by Affirmative, Verbal Request
Waiver is most commonly understood as an affirmative, 
  verbal request.Â  United States v. Goldberg, 67 F.3d 1092, 1099 (3d Cir. 
  1995); State v. Boykin, 324 S.C. 552, 556, 478 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 
  1996).Â  To effectuate a valid waiver of the right to counsel, the two-pronged 
  Faretta test must be met in which the accused is (1) advised of his right 
  to counsel and (2) adequately warned of the dangers of self-representation.Â  
  Prince v. State, 301 S.C. 422, 423-24, 392 S.E.2d 462, 463 (1990) (citing 
  Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806, 95 S.Ct. 2525, 45 L.Ed.2d 562 (1975)).Â  
  The trial judge must determine whether there is a knowing and intelligent waiver 
  by the defendant.Â  State v. Dixon, 269 S.C. 107, 236 S.E.2d 419 (1977) 
  (citing Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458, 58 S.Ct. 1019, 82 L.Ed. 1461 
  (1938)).Â  If the trial judge fails to address the disadvantages of appearing 
  pro se, as required by the second prong of Faretta, 
  â€œthis Court will look to the record to determine whether petitioner had sufficient 
  background or was apprised of his rights by some other source.â€Â  Prince, 
  301 S.C. at 424, 392 S.E.2d at 463; accord Wroten v. State, 301 
  S.C. 293, 294, 391 S.E.2d 575, 576 (1990).Â  While a specific inquiry by the 
  trial judge expressly addressing the disadvantages of a pro se 
  defense is preferred, the ultimate test is not the trial judge's advice but 
  rather the defendant's understanding.Â  Gardner v. State, 351 S.C. 407, 
  411-12, 570 S.E.2d 184, 186 (2002); Wroten, 301 S.C. at 294, 391 S.E.2d 
  at 576.Â  If the record demonstrates the defendant's decision to represent 
  himself was made with an understanding of the risks of self-representation, 
  the requirements of a voluntary waiver will be satisfied.Â  Id.
Pellucidly by his absence, Thompson did not make 
  an affirmative, verbal request to waive counsel.
2.Â  Waiver by Conduct
A defendant may waive his right to counsel through 
  his conduct.Â  United States v. Goldberg, 67 F.3d 1092, 1100 (3d Cir. 
  1995); State v. Jacobs, 271 S.C. 126, 128, 245 S.E.2d 606, 608 (1978); 
  State v. Boykin, 324 S.C. 552, 556, 478 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
  Most courts have held that the defendant must first be warned that his misconduct 
  will thereafter be treated as a waiver.Â  Boykin, 324 S.C. at 556, 478 
  S.E.2d at 691.Â  â€œ[T]o the extent that the defendantâ€™s actions are examined under 
  the doctrine of â€˜waiver,â€™ there can be no valid waiver of the Sixth Amendment 
  right to counsel unless the defendant also receives Faretta warnings.â€Â  
  Goldberg, 67 F.3d at 1100.Â  Any subsequent misconduct will be treated 
  as a â€œwaiver by conduct.â€Â  Boykin, 324 S.C. at 556, 478 S.E.2d at 690.
In State v. Cain, 277 S.C. 210, 284 S.E.2d 
  779 (1981), the appellant was tried in absentia and without counsel.Â  
  Cain was represented by counsel at a preliminary hearing and both he and his 
  attorney were aware the case was coming up for trial.Â  Id. at 210, 284 
  S.E.2d at 779.Â  The court found Cain was cognizant of his duty to keep in contact 
  with his attorney and the court.Â  Id.Â  The court held a waiver of the 
  right to counsel was inferable from his omissions.Â  Id. at 211, 284 S.E.2d 
  at 779.
Although in the present case Thompson was tried 
  in absentia and without counsel, the facts in Cain are 
  quite different.Â  Unlike Thompson, Cain was represented by counsel at a preliminary 
  hearing.Â  Cain edifies:

The appellant was released on a general appearance bond and 
  was represented by counsel at a preliminary hearing.Â  Both the appellant and 
  his attorney knew the case was coming up for trial. The appellant knew he had 
  a duty to stay in touch with his attorney and with the court.
We held in State v. Jacobs, 271 S.C. 126, 245 S.E.2d 
  606 (1978) that a waiver of the right to counsel can be inferred from a defendant's 
  actions. In this case, the appellant failed to fulfill the conditions of his 
  appearance bond and neglected to keep contact with his attorney, although he 
  knew his trial was imminent. We think a waiver of the right to counsel is inferrable 
  [sic] from these omissions.

Id. at 210-11, 284 S.E.2d at 779 (footnote 
  omitted).
The case of State v. Jacobs, 271 S.C. 126, 
  245 S.E.2d 606 (1978), analyzes a trial scenario where the appellant participated 
  at trial, but did not have counsel.Â  The appellant was not indigent.Â Â  The trial 
  judge urged him on several occasions to retain a lawyer.Â  The case was continued 
  at least once to enable the appellant to hire an attorney.Â  Id. at 127, 
  245 S.E.2d at 607.Â  The judge asked an attorney with the Public Defenderâ€™s Office 
  to sit with him at trial to offer him advice and assistance.Â  Id.Â  Although 
  the appellant never expressly waived his right to counsel, the court held the 
  appellant waived his right to counsel by his conduct because he was given reasonable 
  time to secure counsel, he was financially capable of retaining counsel, and 
  the court had done all it could to advise him to seek counsel.Â  Id.
The facts in Jacobs are dissimilar to the 
  case sub judice.Â  Jacobs was present in the courtroom, he was 
  financially capable of retaining counsel, the judge had repeatedly encouraged 
  him to get an attorney, the judge continued the case at least on one occasion 
  for him to retain an attorney, and he had the assistance of a public defender 
  at trial.Â  Jacobs is enlightening:

Appellant never expressly waived his right to counsel but 
  the trial judge found that he was very capable of retaining counsel, that the 
  court had done all it could do to urge him to do so, and that he had still not 
  employed a lawyer. The trial judge asked an attorney from the Public Defender's 
  Office to sit with him during his trial to give him advice and assistance. The 
  attorney advised the court that he was totally unprepared for trial but the 
  trial judge said that appellant's inaction had caused the situation. Appellant 
  agreed to allow the attorney to sit with him but indicated that he wanted him 
  to do nothing further in the case. The trial then proceeded.
. . . .
On the facts of this case, we feel that the trial judge allowed 
  appellant, a non-indigent, a reasonable time in which to retain counsel and 
  that appellant did not make a sufficient showing of reasons for his failure 
  to have counsel present. He was on several occasions urged to retain counsel 
  and a phone was made available to him and additional time was given him in order 
  for him to make arrangements. When, on the day of trial, counsel was not present, 
  appellant did not name his attorney, if one had been retained, nor did he indicate 
  when counsel would be available. He gave no reasons for the absence of counsel 
  other than that he had been expecting his brother to bring a lawyer.

We conclude that, by his conduct, appellant waived his right 
  to counsel.
Id. at 127-28, 245 S.E.2d at 607-08.
An excellent academic explication of an appellant 
  tried in absentia and without representation is Pennsylvania 
  v. Ford, 715 A.2d 1141 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1998).Â  The appellant was originally 
  appointed counsel.Â  Id. at 1143.Â  He requested a continuance in order 
  to find private counsel.Â  Id.Â  The court then approved the withdrawal 
  of the court-appointed counsel.Â  Id.Â  Two weeks before jury selection 
  was initiated, the appellant fled the jurisdiction after violating his probation 
  in a prior unrelated case.Â  Id.Â  When the appellant did not appear for 
  jury selection, his private counsel filed a motion to withdraw, arguing that 
  the appellant had not paid a large portion of his fee and his absence impeded 
  trial preparation.Â  Id.Â  The court granted the motion and proceeded to 
  try the appellant in absentia and without counsel.Â  Id.Â  
  The court found the appellant did not validly waive his right to counsel because 
  there was no inquiry on the record as to whether the appellant was aware of 
  his rights or whether he knowingly waived them.Â  Id. at 1144.Â  The court 
  observed that this type of inquiry is â€œquite obviously impossibleâ€ when a defendant 
  fails to appear in court.Â  Id.Â  However, the court ruled that â€œ[f]ailure 
  to appear . . . is not tantamount to a knowing waiver.â€Â  Id.Â  The appellantâ€™s 
  fugitive status was not a per se waiver nor could it be punished 
  by the â€œnegation of constitutional rights.â€Â  Id.Â  His fugitive status 
  was a separate wrong with its own consequences.Â  Id.
While Thompson did not have counsel withdraw at 
  the brink of trial, he similarly was not queried on the record as to whether 
  he was aware of his rights or whether he knowingly waived them.Â  The Ford 
  court acknowledged the impracticability of asking the defendant on the record 
  when he does not appear in court, but still found that a failure to appear does 
  not equate a knowing waiver.Â  Likewise, Thompsonâ€™s failure to appear does NOT 
  rise to the level of waiver.
The Indiana Court of Appeals thoroughly analyzed 
  a trial in absentia involving a defendant unrepresented by counsel.Â  
  Slayton v. Indiana, 755 N.E.2d 232 (Ind. Ct. App. 2001).Â  Slayton appeared 
  in court three times before trial in which the court mentioned counsel but never 
  advised him of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation.Â  Id. 
  at 234.Â  The State argued that Slayton never requested the court to appoint 
  counsel and that his failing to appear at trial â€œprevented the trial court from 
  providing him with counsel or from even determining his intention to have counsel.â€Â  
  Id. at 235.Â  Hence, the State maintained Slayton waived his right because 
  he never clearly exercised it one way or another.Â  Id.Â  The court found 
  the Stateâ€™s argument was flawed.Â  First, the court determined that Slayton wanted 
  â€œstandbyâ€ counsel.Â  Id. at 236.Â  Next, the court acknowledged the failure 
  to advise Slayton of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation relating 
  to the Faretta two-prong test.Â  Id.Â  Finally, the court recognized 
  the presumption against a waiver of the right to counsel.Â  Id.Â  The court 
  ruled â€œ[t]he Stateâ€™s argument for â€˜waiverâ€™ would turn this presumption on its 
  head, requiring a defendant to clearly exercise rights that were never explained 
  to him.â€Â  Id.Â  Based upon the record being void of any implication that 
  Slayton understood the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation, the 
  court held the facts and circumstances of the case did not warrant a finding 
  of a knowing and intelligent waiver of counsel.Â  Id.
The case at bar is most similar to the facts in 
  Slayton.Â  Both defendants were tried in absentia, unrepresented 
  by counsel, and had appeared in court several times before trial.Â  Neither of 
  the defendants was advised of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation 
  under Faretta.Â  Furthermore, the record in the instant case does not 
  reveal any inference that Thompson understood the dangers and disadvantages 
  of self-representation.Â  Thompson did not have a prior record which would have 
  familiarized him with the criminal court system.Â  Abiding by the presumption 
  against a waiver of the right to counsel, we conclude Thompson did not waive 
  his right to counsel through his conduct when he never was apprised of his right 
  nor the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation.
  B.              
Forfeiture 
   
Some courts recognize forfeiture as a means to 
  waive the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  A defendant can forfeit his right 
  to counsel irrespective of his knowledge of either the consequences of his actions 
  or the dangers of self-representation.Â  United States v. Goldberg, 67 
  F.3d 1092, 1100 (3d. Cir. 1995).Â  â€œ[B]ecause of the drastic nature of the sanction, 
  forfeiture would appear to require extremely dilatory conduct.Â  On the other 
  hand, a 'waiver by conduct' could be based on conduct less severe than that 
  sufficient to warrant a forfeiture.â€Â  Id. at 1101.Â  Situations where 
  a defendantâ€™s own conduct forfeits his right to counsel are unusual, typically 
  involving a manipulative or disruptive defendant.Â  State v. Coleman, 
  644 N.W.2d 283, 288 (Wis. Ct. App. 2002). 
The Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals in United 
  States v. McLeod identified methods in which a defendant could forfeit counsel:

The Sixth Amendment right to counsel, for example, may be 
  forfeited by a defendantâ€™s failure to retain counsel within a reasonable time, 
  even if this forfeiture causes the defendant to proceed pro se.Â  
  See Fowler, 605 F.2d at 183.Â  Additionally, a defendant who misbehaves 
  in the courtroom may forfeit his constitutional right to be present at trial.Â  
  See e.g., Illinois v. Allen, 397 U.S. 337, 90 S.Ct. 1057, 
  25 L.Ed.2d 353 (1970); Foster v. Wainwright, 686 F.2d 1382, 1388-89 (11th 
  Cir. 1982), cert. denied 459 U.S. 1213, 103 S.Ct. 1209, 75 L.Ed.2d 
  449 (1983).Â  A defendant who causes a witness to be unavailable for trial forfeits 
  his right to confrontation.Â  See United States v. Thevis, 665 
  F.2d 616, 630 (5th Cir. Unit B 1982), cert. denied, 
  459 U.S. 825, 103 S.Ct. 57, 74 L.Ed.2d 61 (1982).Â  A defendant who escapes from 
  custody during his trial waives his Sixth Amendment rights to be present and 
  to confront witnesses during the trial.Â  See Golden v. Newsome, 
  755 F.2d 1478, 1481 (11th Cir. 1985).
By analogy, we conclude that under certain circumstances, 
  a defendant who is abusive toward his attorney may forfeit his right to counsel.Â  


53 F.3d 322, 325 (11th Cir. 1995) (footnotes 
  omitted).Â  McLeod had verbally abused and threatened to harm counsel in a telephone 
  conversation, at least four times had threatened to sue him, and had attempted 
  to persuade counsel to engage in unethical conduct.Â  Id. at 325.Â  His 
  behavior was â€œrepeatedly abusive, threatening, and coercive.â€Â  Id. at 
  326.Â  Consequently, McLeod forfeited his right to counsel.Â  
Misconduct by a defendant directed toward counsel 
  is the quiddity of State v. Boykin, 324 S.C. 552, 478 S.E.2d 689 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  Boykin verbally abused and physically threatened defense counsel.Â  
  The judge granted the request of counsel to be relieved.Â  Id. at 554-55, 
  478 S.E.2d at 689-90.Â  Boykin elucidates:

Although we do not condone Boykin's actions, we do not believe 
  they were so severe as to permanently deprive him of appointed counsel. Both 
  cases which have held a defendant forfeited his right to counsel involved a 
  course of conduct more egregious than the single incident alleged here. Accordingly, 
  we need not decide whether South Carolina should embrace the doctrine of forfeiture 
  because we find that Boykin's conduct in the one event related by Padgett was 
  not sufficient to constitute forfeiture.Â  While the trial judge was certainly 
  justified in granting Padgett's motion to be relieved as counsel, substitute 
  counsel should have been appointed for Boykin. Therefore, the decision of the 
  trial court is reversed and the case remanded for a new trial.

We decline to place our imprimatur upon Thompsonâ€™s 
  conduct or absence.Â  Our declination of approval of Thompsonâ€™s activities does 
  NOT mandate forfeiture of counsel.Â  
CONCLUSION
Forfeiture of counsel is a drastic consequence, 
  requiring more than absence from trial.Â  We rule Thompson did NOT relinquish 
  his right to counsel through forfeiture.Â  
Based on the record in its entirety, we hold Thompson 
  did NOT waive his right to counsel.
He was erroneously deprived of his fundamental 
  right to assistance of counsel.Â  This denial is per se reversible 
  error.Â  Therefore, the decision of the circuit court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  This case was decided without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   [2]  Thompsonâ€™s waiver of his right to be present at 
    trial is not at issue on appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Venture Engineering, Inc.       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tishman Construction Corporation of South Carolina; Timberland Properties, 
        Inc.; The South Carolina Public Service Authority (Santee Cooper); and 
        High Point Capital, LLC,        Defendants,
        Of whom The South Carolina Public Service 
        Authority (Santee Cooper) is        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 3660
Heard May 13, 2003 â€“ Filed July 7, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
G. Michael Smith, of Conway; Julio E. Mendoza, of Columbia; 
  and Mark A. Brunty, of Myrtle Beach; for Appellant.
Elizabeth Warner, of Moncks Corner; Francis B.B. Knowlton, 
  of Columbia; John Hamilton Smith and Stephen P. Groves, both of Charleston; 
  and John Samuel West, of Moncks Corner; for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â Â Â  Venture Engineering, 
  Inc. (â€œVentureâ€) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order, finding Ventureâ€™s mechanicâ€™s 
  lien did not encumber property owned by the South Carolina Public Service Authority 
  (â€œSantee Cooperâ€).Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In 1995, Timberland Properties, Inc. (â€œTimberlandâ€) 
  purchased approximately 422 acres of real property owned by the State of South 
  Carolina but managed by Santee Cooper.Â  As part of the sale, Timberland agreed 
  to begin construction of a â€œtheme parkâ€ within 12 months from the date of the 
  purchase.Â  This provision was later amended, extending the time limit by 90 
  days.Â  If Timberland failed to begin construction within the prescribed period, 
  Santee Cooper had the right to repurchase the property together with all improvements 
  for the original sale price.Â  The original deed and contract, along with the 
  subsequent amendment were properly recorded in the Horry County Register of 
  Deeds.
Subsequently, Timberland hired Venture to perform 
  civil engineering services in connection with Timberlandâ€™s development of the 
  property.Â  However, Timberland failed to pay for Ventureâ€™s services, and Venture 
  filed a mechanicâ€™s lien on the property for $127,786.74 on May 6, 1997.Â  In 
  addition, Timberland failed to begin construction on the theme park as required 
  by its contract with Santee Cooper, and Santee Cooper repurchased the property 
  on May 16, 1997.
In June 1997, Timberland sought Bankruptcy protection 
  under Chapter 7 of the Bankruptcy Code. Several months later, Venture sought 
  to foreclose on its mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  In February 1999, the Bankruptcy Court 
  issued a Notice of Settlement and Sale, in which it advised all Timberland creditors 
  that Timberlandâ€™s bankruptcy trustee intended to submit a proposed settlement 
  to the Bankruptcy Court for its approval.Â  Among other things, the proposed 
  settlement indicated the trustee would sell the property to Santee Cooper free 
  and clear of all liens and encumbrances.Â  In addition, the notice indicated 
  any party objecting to the proposed settlement had to submit a written objection 
  within twenty days, pursuant to Rule 9014, District of South Carolina Bankruptcy 
  Rules.Â  Venture received a copy of the notice, but did not file any objection.
Subsequently, the Bankruptcy Court issued an Approval 
  Order, approving the proposed settlement and sale.Â  The property was then transferred 
  to Santee Cooper, â€œfree and clear of all liens and encumbrances in accordance 
  with 11 U.S.C. Â§ 363.â€
Following the conclusion of the bankruptcy proceedings, 
  Ventureâ€™s foreclosure action was referred to a master.Â  The master dismissed 
  Ventureâ€™s claim with prejudice, finding Ventureâ€™s claim was barred because Venture 
  failed to object to the sale of the property by the bankruptcy trustee free 
  and clear of all liens and encumbrances.Â  Venture appeals.
DISCUSSION
Among other things, Venture argues the master erred 
  in finding its claim was barred because it failed to object in Bankruptcy Court 
  to the proposed settlement.Â  We disagree.
The United States Bankruptcy Code provides, in 
  relevant part: â€œ(b)(1) The trustee, after notice and a hearing, may . . . sell 
  . . . property of the [bankruptcy] estate . . . (f) free and clear of any interest 
  in such property of an entity . . . if . . . (2) such entity consents . . . 
  .â€Â  11 U.S.C. Â§ 363 (1999); see also In re Collins, 180 B.R. 447, 
  450 (Bankr. E.D. Va. 1995).Â  South Carolinaâ€™s local bankruptcy rules provide 
  the specific notice procedures the trustee must follow before the trustee may 
  sell the property.Â  SC LBR 6004-1(b) states: â€œMotions to sell property free 
  and clear of liens pursuant to . . . 11 U.S.C. Â§ 363 must be made using the 
  passive notice procedure prescribed by SC LBR 9014-2 . . . and must be served 
  on all parties in interest.â€Â  See SC LBR 9014‑2 (stating, when 
  giving notice of a proposed settlement and sale, parties must adhere to South 
  Carolinaâ€™s local clerkâ€™s instructions).
The local clerkâ€™s instructions provide, in relevant 
  part, â€œthe moving party must serve on . . . any other interested party . . . 
  (1) The motion; (2) The notice of hearing of the motion; [and] (3) A proposed 
  order . . . .â€Â  SC CI 9014-2(b).Â  Furthermore, SC CI 9014-2(c) provides â€œAny 
  response, return and/or objection to the motion must be served no later 
  than twenty (20) days following the service date of the motion . . . .Â  (2)Â  
  If the objection time expires without the filing of an [sic] response, return 
  and/or objection or other request, the proposed order will be promptly submitted 
  to the judge for his consideration.â€ (Emphasis added); cf. In 
  re Parrish, 171 B.R. 138, 140 (Bankr. M.D. Fla. 1994) (indicating a hearing 
  need only be held when, after having received notice, a creditor objects to 
  the proposed settlement).
Venture received notice pursuant to the rules and 
  clerkâ€™s instruction noted above and was given an opportunity to object within 
  twenty days.Â  Venture did not object, but argues on appeal it was not required 
  to do so.Â  Venture bases this argument on its misplaced belief that because 
  both the bankruptcy trustee and Santee Cooper claimed title to the same property, 
  Venture was not required to make its claim until after the Bankruptcy Court 
  determined which entity owned the property.
However, a bankruptcy trustee â€œhas the rights and 
  powers of a hypothetical creditor possessing a judicial lien which attaches 
  upon commencement of the case; the law treats a trustee as a hypothetical lien 
  creditor.Â  See 11 U.S.C. Â§ 544.â€Â  In re Parrish, 171 B.R. at 141 
  (internal quotations omitted).Â  Once Timberland filed for bankruptcy, the bankruptcy 
  trustee took a judicial lien on the property.Â  Thus, notwithstanding the adversarial 
  position taken by Santee Cooper, the property remained subject to the trusteeâ€™s 
  judicially created lien until the date of the sale.Â  See id. (holding 
  â€œ[o]nce the property is sold and relinquished by the Trustee, the property ceases 
  to belong to the estate, and the Trusteeâ€™s fictional hypothetical lien terminates 
  on the date of saleâ€).Â  As such, we find Venture was required to timely object 
  to the trusteeâ€™s Notice of Proposed Settlement and Sale if it wished to protect 
  its interest in the property itself or the proceeds of the sale of the property.
Having failed to object to the sale, Venture consented 
  to having its lien extinguished.Â  See FutureSource, LLC v. Reuters 
  Ltd., 312 F.3d 281, 284 (7th Cir. 2002), cert. denied, 123 S. Ct. 
  1769 (2003) (holding, although Futuresource was not a party to the bankruptcy 
  proceeding, it was a party in interest, and thus, it had a right to raise and 
  appear to be heard on any issue in the case.Â  Moreover, â€œit was notified of 
  [the sale and the purchase agreement] and had access to a copy of the agreement 
  yet it did not object to the sale or challenge the bankruptcy courtâ€™s order.â€); 
  see also In re Elliot, 94 B.R. 343 (E.D. Pa. 1988) (holding section 
  363(f)(2) permitted the bankruptcy trustee â€œto sell the property free and clear 
  of all liens because [the creditor] consented to the sale . . . by failing to 
  make any timely objection after receiving notice of the saleâ€).Â  Therefore, 
  we find the master did not err in dismissing Ventureâ€™s mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure 
  action.
CONCLUSION [1] 
For the foregoing reasons, the masterâ€™s order dismissing 
  Ventureâ€™s claim with prejudice is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, J., and BEATTY, Acting Judge, concur.

 
   
    [1]  Because of our holding with respect to Ventureâ€™s failure to object 
    to the proposed settlement, we need not reach Ventureâ€™s other issues on appeal.

title: Neely v. Thomasson
description: Discusses whether the probate court acted within its subject matter jurisdiction in determining paternity for purposes of establishing heirs of a decedentâ€™s estate and whether the issue of paternity was adjudicated in a prior action in which decedent was divorced from claimantâ€™s mother.
text:
STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
      Lyle Neely and Gloria Russel Ballard, as Personal Representative
      of the estate of Rita Russell, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
      Nancy Thomasson, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate 
        of John Thomas Neely, and Josephine Morgan Wells, of whom, Nancy Thomasson, 
        individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of John Thomas 
        Neely is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3661
Heard April 10, 2003 â€“ Filed July 14, 
  2003

VACATED IN PART and
REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
Carolyn W. Rogers, of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
S. Jackson Kimball, III, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
      
    
  


STROM, Acting Judge:Â  Nancy Thomasson appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the probate courtâ€™s order, which determined 
  Thomasson was not a child of John Thomas Neely, and therefore, not an heir of 
  his estate.Â  We vacate in part and reverse and remand in part.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Thomasson was born on December 1, 1943.Â  Her birth 
  certificate lists her name as Nancy Jane Neely and her parents as John Thomas 
  Neely and Josephine Morgan.Â  Thomassonâ€™s parents, unmarried at the time of her 
  birth, married seven months later.Â  They separated approximately six months 
  after their marriage, but did not immediately seek a divorce.
In 1963, Morgan brought an action, seeking a divorce 
  from Neely.Â  She alleged one child was born to her and Neely.Â  Neely never answered 
  Morganâ€™s Complaint and was held in default.Â  The matter was referred to a special 
  master, who was to conduct a hearing, take evidence, and issue a report to the 
  circuit court, which would then enter a final order.Â  Pursuant to the order 
  of reference, the special referee issued a report in which he stated the evidence 
  adduced during the hearing proved one child was born to the parties and the 
  child was emancipated at the time of the hearing.Â  This finding was incorporated 
  by the circuit court in its final order granting Morgan a divorce.Â  Neither 
  party appealed this final decree.
In 1998, Neely died intestate.Â  Subsequently, Thomasson 
  asserted a claim in probate court, alleging she was Neelyâ€™s daughter, and therefore, 
  an heir to his estate.Â  Thomasson was appointed as the estateâ€™s personal representative.Â  
  Thereafter, Neelyâ€™s brother and sister, Lyle Neely and Rita Russell (collectively, 
  â€œNeelyâ€™s Siblingsâ€), commenced this action, alleging Thomasson was not Neelyâ€™s 
  child and seeking judicial determination of Neelyâ€™s heirs. 
  [1] 
During the contested proceeding, the probate court 
  admitted blood-type evidence, indicating Thomasson had a blood type that could 
  not have been produced from the blood types of Neely and Morgan.Â  Additionally, 
  the probate court admitted DNA evidence, showing a 0.00% probability Thomasson 
  was Neelyâ€™s daughter.
Following the hearing, the probate court found Thomasson 
  was neither Neelyâ€™s natural nor adopted child and no adjudication of paternity 
  occurred prior to Neelyâ€™s death.Â  Thus, the probate court ruled Thomasson was 
  not Neelyâ€™s heir for purposes of intestate succession.Â  Thomasson appealed the 
  probate courtâ€™s order to the circuit court, which affirmed the order.Â  Thomasson 
  appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Subject Matter Jurisdiction
For the first time, Thomasson argues the probate 
  court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to adjudicate the issue of paternity.Â  
  Therefore, Thomasson argues this Court should vacate the probate courtâ€™s entire 
  order.Â  We agree the probate court did not have subject matter jurisdiction 
  to adjudicate the issue of paternity.Â  However, we do not agree this Court must 
  vacate the entire order.
Initially we note, our rules of error preservation 
  do not bar Thomassonâ€™s argument because she asserts a defect in the probate 
  courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See Tatnall v. Gardner, 
  350 S.C. 135, 137, 564 S.E.2d 377, 378 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe issue of subject 
  matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time including when raised for the 
  first time on appeal to this Court.â€).
Our Court recently decided an almost identical case 
  in Simmons v. Bellamy, 349 S.C. 473, 562 S.E.2d 687 (Ct. App. 2002) (per 
  curiam).Â  We find Simmons controlling in the current situation.Â  In Simmons, 
  the probate court, relying on its jurisdiction to determine heirs during an 
  intestacy proceeding, issued an order in which it determined an infant born 
  after the decedentâ€™s death was the child of the decedent, and thus, his heir.Â  
  349 S.C. at 475, 562 S.E.2d at 688.Â  The circuit court affirmed the probate 
  courtâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  Id.Â  This Court sua sponte raised 
  the issue of whether the probate court had subject matter jurisdiction to adjudicate 
  paternity and held it did not.Â  Id. at 476-77, 562 S.E.2d at 689.
When rendering its decision, the Simmons court 
  considered the jurisdiction of both the family court and the probate court.Â  
  This Court specifically considered whether the probate court could adjudicate 
  paternity as part of its inherent jurisdiction to determine heirs during an 
  intestacy proceeding.Â  However, after reviewing the applicable statutory authority, 
  specifically South Carolina Code Annotated section 20-7-420 (1976) (stating 
  â€œ[t]he family court shall have exclusive jurisdiction: . . . (7) To hear and 
  determine actions to determine the paternity of an individualâ€), this Court 
  unequivocally found the family court is vested with exclusive subject matter 
  jurisdiction to adjudicate matters of paternity even when the question of a 
  decedentâ€™s heirs is properly pending before the probate court.Â  Simmons, 
  349 S.C. at 476-77, 562 S.E.2d at 689.
We find both the reasoning and result reached in Simmons 
  to be compelling.Â  The probate courtâ€™s jurisdiction extends to all matters â€œrelated 
  to . . . [the] determination of heirsâ€ â€œexcept as otherwise specifically provided.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(a) (Supp. 2002).Â  However, section 20-7-420(7) of 
  the Childrenâ€™s Code reserves to the family court exclusive jurisdiction for 
  the adjudication of paternity.Â  Therefore, we find the probate courtâ€™s jurisdiction 
  is limited by section 20-7-420(7).Â  Moreover, section 20‑7‑420(7) 
  expressly provides the family court is to adjudicate paternity in intestacy 
  cases that have already been or will be commenced in probate court.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(7) (stating â€œ[t]he [paternity] action may be brought 
  . . . , if the father is deceased, in the county in which proceedings for probate 
  of his estate have been or could be commencedâ€).
Thus, having reviewed the applicable statutory authority 
  and relevant case law, we see no reason for this Court to depart from our decision 
  in Simmons.Â  However, although we agree with Thomassonâ€™s contention that 
  the probate court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to determine her paternity, 
  we do not agree we must vacate the probate courtâ€™s entire order.Â  As 
  noted above, the probate court has jurisdiction to determine heirs in an intestacy 
  proceeding.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(a)(i).Â  Thus, we find it necessary 
  to vacate only that portion of the probate courtâ€™s order in which it purported 
  to adjudicate Thomassonâ€™s paternity.
II. Prior Adjudication of Paternity
Having determined the probate court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction to adjudicate Thomassonâ€™s paternity, we must next decide 
  whether the court erred in finding the Neely-Morgan divorce decree was not a 
  final adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s paternity.
In relevant part, South Carolina Code Annotated section 
  62-2-109 (Supp. 2002) states â€œ[i]f . . . a relationship of parent and child 
  must be established to determine succession . . . (2)(ii) the paternity is established 
  by an adjudication commenced before the death of the father.â€Â  Thus, we must 
  determine whether the Neely-Morgan divorce decree, clearly issued prior to Neelyâ€™s 
  death, was a final adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s paternity.

â€œAny judgment or decree, leaving some further act to 
  be done by the court before the rights of the parties are determined [is not 
  final]; but if it so completely fixes the rights of the parties that the 
  court has nothing further to do in the action, then it is final.â€

Adickes v. Allison & Bratton, 21 S.C. 245, 
  259 (1884) (alteration and emphasis added) (quoting Freeman Judgments 
  Â§ 12), cited with approval in Mid-State Distribs., Inc. v. Century 
  Imports, Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 335, 426 S.E.2d 777, 780 (1993).Â  A decree 
  of divorce is generally a final judgment of the court.Â  Culbertson v. Clemens, 
  322 S.C. 20, 23, 471 S.E.2d 163, 164 (1996); cf. Corbin v. Kohler 
  Co., 351 S.C. 613, 621, 571 S.E.2d 92, 97 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe final written 
  order contains the binding instructions which are to be followed by the parties.â€).
Forty years ago, Morgan brought an action against 
  Neely.Â  Morgan sought a divorce and asserted Thomasson was the partiesâ€™ only 
  child.Â  Neely never answered Morganâ€™s Complaint and was held in default.Â  The 
  matter was referred to a special master, who conducted a hearing, took evidence, 
  and issued a report to the circuit court.Â  In the special refereeâ€™s report, 
  he stated the evidence adduced during the hearing proved one child was born 
  to the parties and the child was emancipated at the time of the hearing.Â  This 
  finding was incorporated by the circuit court in its final order granting Morgan 
  a divorce.Â  Neither party appealed.

Having reviewed the record, including the original 
  documents involved in the Neely-Morgan divorce action, we find the probate court 
  erred in concluding the divorce decree was not a final adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s 
  paternity.Â  Morgan alleged Thomasson was Neelyâ€™s child and Neely did not respond.Â  
  Neely had the opportunity to contest Thomassonâ€™s paternity at the hearing and 
  did not do so.Â  This Court need not speculate why Neely did not contest Thomassonâ€™s 
  paternity during the divorce proceedings, but rather must only confirm Neely 
  was given the opportunity to do so.Â  Cf. Sub-zero Freezer Co. v. R.J. 
  Clarkson Co., 308 S.C. 188, 191, 417 S.E.2d 569, 571 (1992) (indicating 
  by analogy, â€œclaims [that] were either litigat[ed] in the prior actions or could 
  have been so litigatedâ€ may not be relitigated in a subsequent action). 
In this case, the courtâ€™s order, granting Morgan a 
  divorce and finding the parties had one child, clearly â€œdisposed of every issue 
  in the case, directed judgmentâ€ and contained binding instructions for the parties.Â  
  See Adickes, 21 S.C. at 259; Corbin, 351 S.C. at 621, 571 
  S.E.2d at 97.Â  Because Neely never appealed the final decree it is the law of 
  the case and cannot now be challenged or ignored.Â  See  ML-Lee 
  Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 
  S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997) (holding an unappealed ruling is the law of the case 
  and cannot be later challenged).Â  Thus, we find the divorce decree was a final 
  adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s paternity prior to Nellyâ€™s death as contemplated 
  by section 62‑2-109(2)(ii).
We believe our holding supports the important public 
  policy interest of upholding the finality of judgments rendered by the courts 
  of this State, particularly when those judgments involve issues relating to 
  children.Â  Cf. Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., Op. No. 25627 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed Apr. 14, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 13 at 51, 63) (stating 
  South Carolina courts have long â€œrecognize[d] that important benefits are achieved 
  by the preservation of final judgmentsâ€).Â  Were we to hold otherwise, we would 
  be permitting Neelyâ€™s Siblings to assert challenges to Thomassonâ€™s paternity 
  that Neely chose not to assert.
Thus, because we find the divorce decree was a 
  final adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s paternity, we find the probate court erred 
  further in its determination of Neelyâ€™s heirs.Â  Therefore, based on our holding 
  that Thomasson is Neelyâ€™s child for purposes of intestacy proceedings, we remand 
  the case for the probate court to redetermine the heirs of Neelyâ€™s estate and 
  redistribute his estate in accordance with this opinion.
CONCLUSION 
 [2] 
Because the probate court did not have subject matter 
  jurisdiction to adjudicate Thomassonâ€™s paternity and erred in deciding the Neely-Morgan 
  divorce decree was not a final adjudication of Thomassonâ€™s paternity, the probate 
  courtâ€™s order is
VACATED IN PART and REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART.
HOWARD, J., concurs.
STILWELL, J., concurs in part and dissents in part in a separate 
  opinion.
STILWELL, J.:Â  (concurring in part and dissenting 
  in part):Â  I agree fully with the majorityâ€™s discussion and conclusion regarding 
  Issue I, the subject matter jurisdiction of the probate court to determine paternity.Â  
  However, I disagree with the majorityâ€™s view on Issue II and respectfully dissent 
  therefrom.
Although neither res judicata nor claim or issue 
  preclusion is strictly involved here because of the intervention of the statute, 
  much of the same analysis that would be required under those doctrines should 
  be utilized here.Â  See generally Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 
  328 S.C. 201, 216-17, 493 S.E.2d 826, 834-35 (1997).Â  There is, however, one 
  significant difference.Â  The statute requires an adjudication of paternity, 
  not merely an opportunity for an adjudication.Â  In the final analysis, I do 
  not believe the divorce decree constituted an adjudication of paternity within 
  the contemplation of the statute.Â  
A review of the divorce proceeding is revealing.Â  
  The action was commenced by a complaint containing six brief factual paragraphs 
  together with two even more brief paragraphs setting forth the relief requested.Â  
  The only factual paragraph related to paternity alleged that to the union one 
  child, Nancy Jane Neely Wells, was born â€œwho is now married and no longer dependent 
  on the plaintiff for support.â€Â  No relief was requested of the court relating 
  to this child, the prayer being limited to a divorce and â€œany other and further 
  relief as to the court may seem just and proper.â€Â  The defendant, John Thomas 
  Neely, defaulted.Â  A reference was held before a special referee.Â  In the minutes 
  of the reference, one question was asked about the child, as follows:Â  
Q:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  I believe there was one child born 
  to this union and that child is now grown and married?
A:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir.
That is the sum and substance of the testimony as 
  to paternity.Â  The referee then issued his report, which contains only one sentence 
  related to the child:Â  â€œThe evidence further showed that the parties to this 
  action are the parents of one child, who is now grown and married, and that 
  since this child is now married, there is no question of custody or support.â€Â  
  None of the findings and recommendations by the special referee relate to the 
  child or the question of paternity.Â  There followed a perfunctory decree of 
  the court adopting in full the recommendations of the special referee and awarding 
  the plaintiff a divorce, without even mentioning the existence of a child.
Under these circumstances, it is clear 
  that this action established only that the parties were entitled to a divorce 
  from one another.Â  However, the issue of the paternity of the child was not 
  necessary to that conclusion.Â  Paternity was never actually litigated, nor did 
  it have to be.
I would, therefore, affirm the probate 
  court on this issue.

 
   
    [1]  During the course of these proceedings, Rita Russell died, but her 
    estateâ€™s personal representative has continued in the same posture on her 
    behalf.Â  Thus, the parties to the action remain the same and this change does 
    not affect the outcome of the case.

 
   
    [2]  Because of our holdings with respect to the probate courtâ€™s lack 
    of subject matter jurisdiction and error in determining the Neely-Morgan divorce 
    decree was not a prior adjudication of paternity, we need not reach Thomassonâ€™s 
    other issues on appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Collins Entertainment Corp., Respondent,
v.
Coats and Coats Rental Amusement, d/b/a Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch 
        Bingo, Wayne Coats, individually, and American Bingo & Gaming Corp.,
Defendants,
Of whom American Bingo & Gaming Corp. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Master in Equity

Opinion No. 3596Â 
Heard December 10, 2002 â€“ Filed February 
  3, 2003
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled July 
  21, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Timothy G. Quinn, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Stephen L. Brown, Edward D. Buckley, 
  Jr., Donald J. Davis, Jr. and Stephen P. Groves, Sr., all of Charleston, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  


GOOLSBY, J.:   Collins 
  Entertainment Corp. (Collins) brought this action against (1) Coats and Coats 
  Rental Amusement, d/b/a Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo, (2) Wayne Coats, 
  individually, and (3) American Bingo & Gaming Corp. (ABG), alleging various 
  causes of action arising out of ABGâ€™s removal of Collinsâ€™ coin machines from 
  Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo.Â  The case was referred to the Charleston 
  County master-in-equity for trial with authority to enter a final judgment.Â  
  ABG appeals (1) the masterâ€™s finding that it intentionally interfered in a lease 
  for the placement of Collinsâ€™ video poker machines in the two business establishments 
  and (2) the punitive damages award.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
T.A. Coats and his wife Darlene owned 
  or operated a business known as Coats and Coats Rental Amusement.Â  Wayne 
  Coats, their son, also appears to have been involved in the business.Â 
Coats and Coats Rental Amusement operated two bingo 
  halls, Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo, at two different locations.Â  
  The locations had been procured by T.A. Coats subject to written real estate 
  leases between him and the individual property owners.
On March 28, 1996, Collins entered 
  into a six-year lease agreement with â€œCoats and Coats Rental Amusements d/b/a 
  Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo and Wayne Coats, individuallyâ€ for 
  the exclusive right to lease video poker machines at both locations.Â  The 
  parties were to split the revenues from operating the machines.Â  The 
  agreement further provided that, if the premises were sold, the buyer was to 
  assume the lease.Â  Wayne Coats signed the agreement individually and 
  on behalf of Coats and Coats Rental Amusement.
In 1997, ABG entered into negotiations 
  with T.A. Coats to purchase the assets of the Ponderosa and Shipwatch businesses 
  and to assume the ground leases to the properties on which they operated.Â  
  The purchase and sale agreement required Coats and Coats to indemnify ABG 
  in the event ABG was sued for interfering with the video poker machine contract.Â  
  Although T.A. Coats made ABG aware of the agreement with Collins, ABG 
  did not assume the lease and instead removed Collinsâ€™ machines from the premises.Â 
Collins then brought this action against Coats 
  and Coats, Wayne Coats, and ABG.Â  In its complaint, Collins asserted a claim 
  for breach of contract against Coats and Coats and Wayne Coats. Collins further 
  asserted causes of action for intentional interference with a contract, civil 
  conspiracy, and unfair trade practices against ABG.
At trial, the master dismissed the civil conspiracy 
  cause of action and found in favor of ABG on the unfair trade practices 
  claim.Â  The master, however, determined ABG was liable for intentional 
  interference with Collinsâ€™ contract and awarded actual damages of $157,449.66 
  and punitive damages of $1,569,013.00. 
  [1] Â  The master denied ABGâ€™s post-trial motions.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Motion to Amend Answer
ABG first contends the master erred in denying 
  its motion to amend its answer to conform to the evidence presented at trial.Â Â  
  We find no error. 
In its answer, ABG stated:Â  â€œThis Defendant admits 
  purchasing the businesses known as Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo from 
  Coats & Coats Rental Agreement and Wayne Coats individually.â€Â  Before 
  calling any witnesses, Collinsâ€™ attorney read this statement into the record 
  verbatim without objection from ABG.Â  At trial, however, Wayne Coats 
  testified that he had no ownership interest in either business when ABG acquired 
  them. 
After the close of ABGâ€™s case, Collinsâ€™ attorney again 
  read the answer into the record.Â  This time, however, ABG moved to amend 
  the answer to conform to the proof.Â  In support of the motion, counsel 
  for ABG claimed: â€œAt the time the [a]nswer was drafted, that was the information 
  provided us.Â  We would ask that the [p]leadings be conformed to the proof presented.â€ 
  [2] Â  Collins objected to the motion, alleging the entire litigation 
  was based on the admission in ABGâ€™s answer.Â  The master denied the motion to 
  amend.
Citing Rule 15(b) of the South Carolina Rules 
  of Civil Procedure, ABG argues the master should have permitted it to amend 
  its answer to conform to the proof offered. 
  [3] Â  We agree, however, with Collins that Rule 15(b) is inapplicable to 
  this situation.Â  As this court stated in Sunvillas Homeowners Assâ€™n v. Square 
  D Co.:Â Â Â Â Â  
The rule covers two situations.Â  First, if an issue not 
  raised by the pleadings is tried by express or implied consent of the parties 
  the court may permit amendment of the pleadings to reflect the issue.Â  Second, 
  if a party objects to the introduction of evidence as not being within the 
  pleadings the court may permit amendment of the pleadings subject to a right 
  to grant a continuance if necessary. [4] 
Here, the issue prompting ABGâ€™s motion to amend was raised 
  in the complaint and admitted by ABG; therefore, the first situation did not 
  apply.Â  Moreover, because no objection was made as to any evidence being outside 
  the pleadings, the master could not have permitted an amendment pursuant to 
  the second part of the rule. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Interference 
  with Contractual RelationsÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
A.
ABG asserts Collins failed to prove the 
  elements of intentional interference with contractual relations.Â  In our view, 
  however, the record has sufficient evidence to support a finding that Collins 
  proved each of the necessary elements.
â€œThe elements of a cause of action for tortious 
  interference with contract are:Â  (1) existence of a valid contract; (2) the 
  wrongdoerâ€™s knowledge thereof; (3) his intentional procurement of its breach; 
  (4) the absence of justification; and (5) resulting damages.â€ 
  [5] 
At trial, ABG contended (1) the parties to the 
  contracts for placement of the video poker machines at Ponderosa Bingo and Shipwatch 
  Bingo were Collins, Wayne Coats, and an entity called Coats and Coats Rental 
  Amusement owned by Wayne Coats; (2) the entity known as Coats and Coats Rental 
  Amusement that was owned by Wayne Coats was a North Carolina entity and separate 
  and distinct from the Coats and Coats owned by T.A. and Darlene Coats; and 
  (3) T.A. Coats held the ground lease on the properties where the businesses 
  were located.Â  ABG maintained that, because it negotiated with only T.A. Coats 
  for the ground leases, it could not have interfered with the video poker machine 
  agreement giving Collins the exclusive right to place its machines at Ponderosa 
  Bingo and Shipwatch Bingo, as that agreement did not involve T.A. Coats.
The master, however, found that Coats and Coats was a business 
  â€œconsisting of Wayne Coatsâ€™ mother and father, T.A. Coats, Wayne Coats, and 
  Darlene Coatsâ€ and that â€œT.A. Coats, Darlene Coats, and Wayne Coats operated

    [34] Â  See Life Ins. Co. of Ga. v. Johnson, 701 So. 2d 524, 
    531 (Ala. 1997) (recognizing that insurance fraud victims have â€œlittle recourse 
    other than through litigationâ€ and that â€œ[p]unitive damages have historically 
    been part of the remedy for such victimsâ€).Â Â  

 
   
    [35] Â  In support of its argument, ABG cited Kinard v. Crosby, 
    315 S.C. 237, 433 S.E.2d 835 (1993) and Collins v. Terry, 303 S.C. 
    358, 400 S.E.2d 783 (Ct. App. 1991).

 
   
    [36] Â  See State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co. v. Campbell, 123
