THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
In the Matter Of The Estate Of Gordon S. Boynton
Ervin Mathias, as Co-Personal Representative of the Estate of Gordon S. 
        Boynton; Gordon Benjamin Kearse; Loraine K. Clark; James G. Kearse; Esther 
        S. Kearse, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Henry A.
Kearse; 
        and June Kearse, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Richard M.
Kearse, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Janice Taylor Clark, Individually and as Co-Personal Representative of 
        the Estate of Gordon S. Boynton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3662
Heard March 12, 2003 â€“ Filed July 21, 
  2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James D. Mosteller, of Columbia, for Appellant.
B. Michael Brackett, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Janice Taylor Clark, the illegitimate daughter of Henry 
  Taylor, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision that the remainder devise to the 
  â€œchild or childrenâ€ of Taylor in Item I of Gordon Boyntonâ€™s will did not include 
  illegitimate children.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Boynton died testate in 1954, devising a life estate in an 
  860 acre farm to Taylor with the remainder to Taylorâ€™s child or children and 
  a contingent remainder to Boyntonâ€™s heirs at law should Taylor die without children. 
  Taylor died in 1995 with Clark as his only issue.Â  On December 6, 2000, Ervin 
  Mathias, as co-personal representative of Boyntonâ€™s estate, and Boyntonâ€™s heirs 
  filed a complaint in probate court seeking a declaratory judgment that Boyntonâ€™s 
  use of the words â€œchild or children,â€ by definition, excluded Clark because 
  she was illegitimate. [1] Â  By agreement of the parties, the matter was 
  submitted on stipulated facts and briefs to the probate court.Â  The probate 
  court found Clark was the â€œsole remainderman of the life estate interestâ€ under 
  Boyntonâ€™s will.Â  Mathias appealed to the circuit court.Â  Clark cross-appealed, 
  alleging the probate court erred in refusing to consider evidence outside the 
  written stipulations.Â  The circuit court dismissed the cross-appeal and reversed 
  the probate court. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen an appeal involves 
  stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is free to review whether 
  the trial court properly applied the law to those facts.â€Â  WDW Props. v. 
  City of Sumter, 342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000).Â  â€œIn such cases, 
  the appellate court owes no particular deference to the trial courtâ€™s legal 
  conclusions.â€Â  J.K. Constr., Inc. v. W. Carolina Regâ€™l Sewer Auth., 336 
  S.C. 162, 166, 519 S.E.2d 561, 563 (2001); see also Duke Power Co. 
  v. Laurens Elec. Coop., Inc., 344 S.C. 101, 104, 543 S.E.2d 560, 561-62 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  On appeal from the final order of the probate court, the circuit 
  court should apply the same standard of review that the Supreme Court or Court 
  of Appeals would apply on appeal.Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 
  S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Clark argues the circuit court erred 
  when it applied 1954 law to construe the language of Boyntonâ€™s will.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the provisions of a will and restrictions on the power 
  of testamentary disposition are determined according to the law in effect at 
  the time of the testatorâ€™s death or the time when the will is executed.Â  79 
  Am. Jur. 2d Wills Â§ 55 (2002); see 4 Bowe-Parker, Page on Wills 
  Â§ 30.27 (1961 & Supp. 2003); 96 C.J.S. Wills Â§ 880 (2001).Â  A will 
  speaks at the time of the testatorâ€™s death.Â  See, e.g., Shelley v. 
  Shelley, 244 S.C. 598, 605, 137 S.E.2d 851, 854 (1964); Landrum v. Branyon, 
  161 S.C. 235, 246-48, 159 S.E. 546, 550 (1931).Â  The modern probate code, which 
  took effect in 1987, states â€œa substantive right in the decedentâ€™s estate accrues 
  in accordance with the law in effect on the date of the decedentâ€™s death.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-100(b)(4) (Supp. 2002).Â  Boynton executed his will in 
  August 1954 and died three weeks later.Â  Thus, the law as it existed in 1954 
  applies.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Clark insists to construe the will the court should apply the law as it existed 
  at the time of the death of the life tenant Taylor.Â  Clark relies on the holding 
  in Freeman v. Freeman, 323 S.C. 95, 100-105, 473 S.E.2d 467, 471-73 (Ct. 
  App. 1996) and Haskell v. Wilmington Trust Co., 304 A.2d 53 (Del.Â  1973) 
  superseded by statute as stated in Annan v. Wilmington Trust Co., 
  559 A.2d 1289, 1292 n.2 (Del. 1989).Â  Freeman concerned an illegitimate 
  heir who was not permitted to inherit from her putative father because she could 
  not satisfy the condition set out in Mitchell v. Hardwick, 297 S.C. 
  48, 51, 374 S.E.2d 681, 683 (1988) that she conclusively establish paternity 
  within the statutory timeframe.Â  Freeman did not involve a testate estate, 
  will construction, or a determination of whether the date of death law or subsequent 
  law controlled the construction of a will.Â  Further, even though Haskell 
  may be persuasive, holdings of the Delaware Supreme Court are not binding on 
  this court.Â  We know no rule or precedent under South Carolina law requiring 
  a testator who makes a devise to a class whose membership could close at a point 
  after the testatorâ€™s death to contemplate all the changes that could occur in 
  the controlling law subsequent to his death.Â  Thus, the law as it existed in 
  1954 controls. 
Clark argues that the application of more current law would require an equal 
  protection analysis under Trimble v. Gordon, 430 U.S. 762 (1977), which 
  held it unconstitutional to create legal distinctions between legitimate and 
  illegitimate childrenâ€™s inheritance rights under statutes of descent and distribution, 
  and its progeny.Â  See Mitchell v. Hardwick, 297 S.C. 48, 374 S.E.2d 
  681 (1988); Wilson v. Jones, 281 S.C. 230, 314 S.E.2d 341 (1984).Â  In 
  the alternative, Clark urges retroactive application of Trimbleâ€™s equal 
  protection doctrine if the court determines 1954 law controls. 
The equal protection analysis in Trimble is inapplicable.Â  
  The question before this court is whether Boynton intended to include illegitimate 
  children when he used the term â€œchild or children of Henry Taylorâ€ in his 1954 
  will.Â  Trimble addresses the question of an illegitimate childâ€™s right 
  or ability to inherit from the intestate estate of his parent pursuant to a 
  state intestacy statute. No state action or intestacy in this case requires 
  the application of equal protection principles.Â  Equal protection is only implicated 
  where there is state action.Â  See Lugar v. Edmondson Oil Co., 
  457 U.S. 922 (1982).Â  Private conduct does not raise an equal protection violation.Â  
  See id.Â  South Carolina law is well settled that a testator may 
  devise his property any way he sees fit, as long as it is not contrary to law 
  or public policy.Â  See Hellams v. Ross, 268 S.C. 284, 290, 233 
  S.E.2d 98, 101 (1977); Brown v. Drake, 275 S.C. 299, 270 S.E.2d 130 (1980).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Clark also relies on the public policy advanced by the probate court 
  that applying 1954 common law would be unconstitutional, contrary to In re 
  Estate of Mercer, 288 S.C. 313, 317, 342 S.E.2d 591, 593 (1986) (citing 
  Trimble, 430 U.S. at 762)Â  (â€œThe stateâ€™s interest in the sanctity of 
  marriage is not substantially related to limiting the inheritance rights of 
  a certain class of illegitimate children.â€).Â  Clarkâ€™s reliance on Mercer 
  is misplaced.Â  Mercer found South Carolina Code Annotated Â§ 21-7-480 
  (1976) unconstitutional on equal protection grounds because it limited what 
  a married man could devise to his mistress or illegitimate child.Â  The facts 
  and result are inapposite to the issue in this case, since no statute prohibits 
  Boynton devising to illegitimate children.Â  Rather, our concern is determining 
  the testatorâ€™s intent under the intestacy law, which he is presumed to know.
Clark argues the court erred in determining the remainder to Taylorâ€™s â€œchild 
  or childrenâ€ in Boyntonâ€™s will excluded illegitimate children.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the law provides that the 
  word â€œchildrenâ€ does not include illegitimate children, except when the testatorâ€™s 
  intent to include them is clear.Â  96 C.J.S. Wills Â§ 934 (2001).Â  The 
  law of South Carolina in 1954 embraced this view.Â  See Shearman v. 
  Angel, 8 S.C. Eq. (Bail. Eq.) 351 (1831) (illegitimate children cannot take 
  with legitimate children where testator devises to â€œchildrenâ€); Wish v. Kershaw, 
  8 S.C. Eq. (Bail. Eq.) 353 (1827) (parol or extrinsic evidence cannot be admitted 
  to show testatorâ€™s intent to include illegitimate takers); see also 
  Coleman Karesh, Wills 7 (1977) (general rule of construction that gift 
  by will to testatorâ€™s children or the children of another includes only legitimate 
  children). 
Clark argues that Wish and Shearman are limited to 
  a narrow set of facts where legitimate and illegitimate children are competing 
  to take from the same devise.Â  She cites the courtâ€™s language in Wish 
  that:Â  â€œIf there had been any legitimate children, they would have been understood 
  to be the persons designated [to take as â€œchildrenâ€]; but there being none, 
  we are driven to the inquiry, whether there are any persons in existence, who 
  had acquired the reputation of children.â€Â  Clark interprets the courtâ€™s opinion 
  to mean that where the only surviving child is illegitimate, then extrinsic 
  evidence may be introduced to prove reputation as a child.Â  Clark then presents 
  the family courtâ€™s determination and evidence presented in that case as proof 
  of her reputation as Henry Taylorâ€™s illegitimate child.Â  
We decline to accept Clarkâ€™s interpretation of the holding in Wish.Â  
  In Wish, the testatrix died leaving an illegitimate grandchild and several 
  legitimate grandchildren.Â  The issue was whether extrinsic or parol evidence 
  could be admitted to prove there was an illegitimate grandchild and that the 
  testatrix intended to include her.Â  Parol evidence was excluded.Â  The court 
  in Wish cited case law that â€œan illegitimate child was held not to be 
  under the description of a child contained in the Will; although the testator 
  knew the state of the family, and that there were several illegitimate, and 
  no legitimate children.â€Â  
Both Clark and Taylor were alive in 1954 when Boynton executed his will.Â  Boynton 
  did not choose to designate Clark as a devisee by name or description.Â  He chose 
  instead to leave a remainder interest to the â€œchild or childrenâ€ of Henry Taylor.Â  
  â€œ[P]rovisions in a will are presumed to be made with an understanding of, and 
  intent to act pursuant to, law and public policy as it exists when the will 
  is executed . . . .â€Â  80 Am. Jur. 2d Wills Â§ 1219 (2002).Â  The common 
  law governing testamentary dispositions in 1954 recognized a narrow definition 
  for the terms â€œchildâ€ and â€œchildrenâ€ to mean only legitimate children.Â  Accordingly, 
  the remainder interest to the â€œchild or children of Henry Taylorâ€ in Boyntonâ€™s 
  will does not include illegitimate children.Â  
Clark argues the circuit court erred in dismissing her cross-appeal 
  that the probate court erred by refusing to consider evidence outside the partiesâ€™ 
  agreed stipulation of facts.Â  We disagree.
Clark agreed to submit the matter to the probate court on stipulated facts.Â  
  She made no objection to limiting the record to the stipulations nor did she 
  reserve the right to present evidence outside of the stipulations.Â  4 C.J.S. 
  Appeal & Error Â§ 185 (1993) (A party who voluntarily acquiesces in 
  or takes a position inconsistent with the right to appeal impliedly waives or 
  is estopped to assert his right to appellate review.).Â  Thus, Clarkâ€™s cross-appeal 
  was properly dismissed.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
CURETON and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  This case overlaps with a closely related paternity action 
    filed by Clark.Â  This court affirmed the family courtâ€™s finding that Taylor 
    was Clarkâ€™s father.Â  Clark v. Clark, Op. No. 2002-UP-145 (S.C. Ct. 
    App. filed Feb. 26, 2002).

STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lighthouse Tennis Club Village Horizontal 
        Property Regime LXVI, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Island Public Service District f/k/a 
        Sea Pines Public Service District, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3664
Heard April 8, 2003 â€“ Filed July 21, 
  2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen E. Carter, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.

Edward E. Bullard and Stephen Bull, both of Hilton Head Island, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â  Lighthouse 
  Tennis Club Horizontal Property Regime LXVI (â€œLighthouseâ€) brought this declaratory 
  judgment action to enjoin South Island Public Service District (â€œSouth Islandâ€) 
  from leasing an access easement granted in connection with the operation of 
  a water and sewer system to telecommunications companies for the unrelated activity 
  of installing and maintaining telecommunications equipment.Â  Lighthouse asserted 
  South Island improperly leased the use of its access easement across Lighthouseâ€™s 
  property to five telecommunications companies (â€œTelecomâ€), allowing them to 
  travel over Lighthouseâ€™s property to install and maintain telecommunications 
  antennas and equipment on the adjoining property owned by South Island.Â  The 
  circuit court ruled the easement does not permit South Island or its assignees 
  to use the easement across Lighthouseâ€™s property for any purpose except â€œto 
  operate and maintain [Lighthouseâ€™s] water and sewer systems.â€Â  South Island 
  appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
During the construction of a condominium complex 
  in the Sea Pines Plantation of Hilton Head Island, the developer installed water 
  and sanitary sewer systems, including the necessary pipes, valves, hydrants, 
  fittings, manholes, and other appurtenances.Â  Following completion of the project, 
  the developer conveyed the condominiums and recreational areas to Lighthouse, 
  and the water and sewer systems to South Islandâ€™s predecessor.Â  As part of this 
  transaction, the developer granted South Islandâ€™s predecessor an easement across 
  its property to the water and sewer companyâ€™s adjoining property on which a 
  water tower and related equipment were located.Â  The adjoining property is landlocked 
  by Lighthouseâ€™s property and is only accessible via the easement.Â  This easement 
  later ran to South Island as the original water companyâ€™s successor in interest.
The easement provides South Island with an â€œeasement 
  . . . over all open area[s], driveways, and parking lots . . . to service the 
  said water and sewer lines and ingress and egress to all adjacent pump stations, 
  wells, tank sites, etc.â€Â  The easement grants South Island â€œthe right to do 
  whatever acts are necessary . . . to operate and maintain the . . . water and 
  sewer systems . . . [and] the right of reasonable access across the properties 
  of [Lighthouse] as may be necessary from time to time to maintain the water 
  and sewer systems.â€
Almost two decades after the easement was granted, 
  South Island began leasing space on top of its water tower to Telecom for the 
  installation of antennae, support equipment, and emergency power generation 
  equipment.Â  To install and maintain the telecommunications equipment, South 
  Island leased to Telecom the use of the easement, permitting Telecom to travel 
  over Lighthouseâ€™s property.Â  Following the execution of the lease agreements, 
  Telecom began moving equipment onto and through the easement.Â  None of the equipment 
  was necessary for maintaining the water or sewer systems.
Lighthouse brought this declaratory judgment action 
  to enjoin South Island from using its property in violation of the easement.Â  
  The parties stipulated the question presented was whether the easementâ€™s use, 
  as provided in the lease agreements, constituted a non-permitted use of the 
  easement property.Â  The circuit court found the easement did not permit South 
  Island to use the easement property for any purpose except â€œto operate and maintain 
  [Lighthouseâ€™s] water and sewer systems.â€Â  Thus, the circuit court ruled the 
  easementâ€™s use, as contemplated in the lease agreements, was a non-permitted 
  use of the easement property.Â  South Island appeals.Â  We affirm.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Extent of Easement
South Island argues the circuit court erred in 
  finding the easement does not permit South Island or its assignees to use the 
  easement across Lighthouseâ€™s property for any purpose except â€œto operate and 
  maintain [Lighthouseâ€™s] water and sewer systems.â€Â  We disagree.
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal 
  nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts 
  v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  â€œ[T]he 
  determination of the extent of a grant of an easement is an action in equity.Â  
  Thus, this Court may take its own view of the evidence . . . .â€Â  Tupper v. 
  Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997) (internal 
  citation omitted).
South Island argues the granting clause of the 
  easement created a complete and absolute estate, which could not be limited 
  by the subsequent description of the easement.Â  As authority for its position, 
  South Island cites and strongly relies on Abbeville County v. Knox, 267 
  S.C. 38, 225 S.E.2d 863 (1976) and Stylecraft, Inc. v. Thomas, 250 S.C. 
  495, 159 S.E.2d 46 (1968) for the proposition that once an estate has been granted 
  in a deed, subsequent words attempting to limit the grant of that estate are 
  ineffective.Â  However, South Islandâ€™s reliance on these two cases is misplaced.

In [Groce v. S. Ry. Co., 164 S.C. 427, 162 S.E. 425 
  (1932) and Stylecraft], the granting clause created a fee simple estate 
  in the grantee.

.Â Â Â Â  .Â Â Â Â  .

[Thus, the] court held in both cases that [any subsequent] 
  limitations upon the use of the property conveyed were ineffectual under the 
  established rule that where the granting clause in a deed conveys a fee simple 
  title that estate may not be cut down by subsequent words in the same instrument.

Douglas v. Med. Investors, Inc., 256 S.C 
  440, 446, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722-23 (1971) (emphasis added). [1] Â  In the present case, the deed in question never granted South 
  Island a fee estate.Â  Thus, we find these cases and the general premise of law 
  for which they are cited are not applicable with respect to the grant of an 
  easement.
The grant of an easement does not create a complete 
  and absolute estate.Â  See id. at 445, 182 S.E.2d at 772 (holding 
  â€œ[a]n easement is . . . not an estate in lands in the usual senseâ€).Â  Rather, 
  â€œ[a]n easement is a right which one person has to use the land of another for 
  a specific purpose,â€ Steele v. Williams, 204 S.C. 124, 132, 28 
  S.E.2d 644, 647 (1944) (emphasis added), and â€œgives no title to the land on 
  which the servitude is imposed.â€Â  Morris v. Townsend, 253 S.C. 628, 635, 
  172 S.E.2d 819, 822 (1970).
â€œThe general rule is that the character of an express 
  easement is determined by the nature of the right and intention of the parties 
  creating it.â€Â  Smith v. Commâ€™rs of Pub. Works of City of Charleston, 
  312 S.C. 460, 467, 441 S.E.2d 331, 336 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  To determine the purpose 
  of the easement, we must evaluate the intention of the parties when the easement 
  was granted.Â  In doing so, the â€œ[c]lear and unambiguous language in grants of 
  easement[s] must be construed according to terms which parties have used, taken, 
  and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  S.C. Pub. Serv. 
  Auth. v. Ocean Forest, Inc., 275 S.C. 552, 554, 273 S.E.2d 773, 774 (1981).Â  
  Moreover, we must effectuate the partiesâ€™ intention â€œunless that intention contravenes 
  some well-settled rule of law or public policy.â€Â  Gardner v. Mozingo, 
  293 S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 391 (1987).Â  
In reviewing the law of this state, we find â€œno 
  settled rule of law which would prohibit [us from] giving effect to the intent 
  of the partiesâ€ when construing the grant of an easement with its subsequent 
  description where both are contained within the same instrument.Â  See 
  Douglas, 256 S.C at 446, 182 S.E.2d at 722.
Contained within the deed conveying the adjoining 
  property to South Islandâ€™s predecessor is the grant of the easement at issue 
  in this case, which provides South Island an

easement . . . over all open area[s], driveways, and parking 
  lots . . . to service the said water and sewer lines and ingress and egress 
  to all adjacent pump stations, wells, tank sites, etc.

.Â Â Â Â  .Â Â Â Â  .

to do whatever acts are necessary . . . to operate and maintain 
  the . . . water and sewer systems . . . [and] the right of reasonable access 
  across the properties of [Lighthouse] as may be necessary from time to time 
  to maintain the water and sewer systems.

Clearly the easement grants South Island the right 
  to use Lighthouseâ€™s property.Â  However, reading the grant in light of the clear 
  and unambiguous terms contained within the easementâ€™s description, we agree 
  with the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that the easement does not permit South Island 
  to use the easement property for any purpose except â€œto operate and maintain 
  [Lighthouseâ€™s] water and sewer systems.â€Â  Thus, because the easement is limited 
  to those acts necessary to operate and maintain the water and sewer systems, 
  we conclude neither South Island nor Telecom is permitted to use the easement 
  as access over Lighthouseâ€™s property to install and maintain telecommunications 
  equipment.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Alter or Amend
After the circuit court issued its initial order, 
  South Island moved pursuant to Rules 52(b), 59(e), and 60(a), SCRCP, to have 
  the circuit court amend its judgment.Â  Specifically, South Island asked the 
  circuit court to review its order and clarify a contradictory factual finding.Â  
  Subsequently, the circuit court issued an amended order in which it changed 
  the contradictory factual finding to conform with its original legal conclusion.Â  
  South Island argues the circuit court erred in amending its order.
In its motion to alter or amend the judgment, South 
  Island asked the circuit court to review its order and clarify a contradictory 
  finding.Â  The rules cited by South Island in its motion specifically provide 
  the circuit court with the authority to amend its findings or correct clerical 
  mistakes.Â  See Rules 52(b), 59(e), & 60(a), SCRCP.Â  Thus, in light 
  of South Islandâ€™s request, we find the circuit court did not err in amending 
  its order to remove any confusion.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order, finding the grant of the easement does not permit South Island or its 
  assignees to use the easement across Lighthouseâ€™s property for any purpose except 
  â€œto operate and maintain [Lighthouseâ€™s] water and sewer systems,â€ and the easementâ€™s 
  use, as contemplated in the lease agreements, constituted a non-permitted use 
  of the easement property is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., and STROM, Acting Judge, concur.

 
   
    [1]  Although Douglas does not directly address Abbeville County, 
    we find its discussion of Groce and Stylecraft consistent with 
    our reading of Abbeville County.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
David Fisher, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Daniel Adam 
        Fisher, Sr., Respondent,
v.
Randy Stevens; Robert E. Poindexter, Individually and d/b/a Low Country 
        Tops Wrecker Service; Speedway of South Carolina, Inc. d/b/a Myrtle Beach 
        Motor Speedway; and National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, Inc.,
Defendants,
Of whom Randy Stevens; Robert E. Poindexter, Individually and d/b/a Low 
        Country Tops Wrecker Service; and Speedway of South Carolina, Inc. d/b/a 
        Myrtle Beach Motor Speedway, are Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3665
Submitted May 12, 2003 â€“ Filed July 
  21, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Willard D. Hanna, Jr. and Nancy 
  K. Tracy, both of Surfside Beach, for Appellants Randy Stephens and Robert E. 
  Poindexter, Individually and d/b/a Low Country Tops Wrecker Service.
Perry D. Boulier, and Ginger 
  D. Goforth, both of Spartanburg, for Secondary Appellant Speedway of South Carolina, 
  Inc. d/b/a Myrtle Beach Motor Speedway.
Richard L. Hinson, of Florence, and Ronald G. Kronthal, of 
  Gaithersburg, Maryland, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CONNOR, J.:Â  Daniel Adams Fisher, Sr., by 
  and through his Conservator and Legal Guardian, Cole Smith, brought this action 
  asserting negligence, gross negligence, and recklessness claims against Randy 
  Stevens, Robert E. Poindexter, individually and d/b/a/ Low Country Tops Wrecker 
  Service, and Speedway of South Carolina, Incorporated (â€œSpeedwayâ€), for injuries 
  suffered after falling from a wrecker truck at the Myrtle Beach Motor Speedway. 
  [1] Â  All parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment seeking a determination 
  of whether the Release and Waiver of Liability and Indemnity Agreement signed 
  by Fisher bars Fisherâ€™s recovery.Â  The trial court partially granted Fisherâ€™s 
  motion for summary judgment as to Stevens and Poindexter.Â  The trial court also 
  denied summary judgment to Speedway, finding a genuine issue of material fact 
  existed concerning whether a master/servant relationship existed between Speedway 
  and Fisher. [2] Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On June 10, 2000, Fisher served on a wrecker crew at 
  Speedway.Â  Fisher signed a release to gain access to the pit area where the 
  wrecker was located and did not pay admission.Â  Fisher had signed the release 
  and served on a wrecker crew on numerous prior occasions.Â  The release states 
  in applicable part:

RELEASE AND WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND INDEMNITY AGREEMENT
THIS SECTION MUST BE CAREFULLY READ AND SIGNED BY THE APPLICANT 
  IN CONSIDERATION OF BEING PERMITTED TO ENTER FOR ANY PURPOSE ANY RESTRICTED 
  AREA (herein defined as including but not limited to the racing surface, pit 
  areas, infield, paddock area, grandstand area, and all walkways, concessions, 
  and other areas appurtenant to any area where any activity related to the EVENT(S) 
  shall take place) or being permitted to compete, officiate, observe, work for, 
  or for any purpose participate in any way in the EVENT(S) . . . .Â  
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  HEREBY RELEASES, WAIVES, DISCHARGES AND COVENANTS 
  NOT TO SUE THE PROMOTERS, PARTICIPANTS, RACING ASSOCIATION, SANCTIONING ORGANIZA- 
  TION OR ANY SUBDIVISION THEREOF, TRACK OPERATOR, TRACK OWNER, OFFICIALS, VEHICLE 
  OWNERS, DRIVERS, PIT CREWS, ANY PERSONS IN ANY RESTRICTED AREA . . . ALL FOR 
  THE PURPOSES HEREIN REFERRED TO AS THE â€œRELEASEESâ€, FROM ALL LIABILITY to the 
  undersigned, his/her personal representatives, assigns, heirs, and next of kin 
  for any and all loss or damage, and any claim or demands therefore on account 
  of injury to the person or property or resulting in death of the undersigned, 
  whether caused by the negligence or gross negligence of the â€œRELEASEESâ€ or otherwise 
  while the undersigned is in or upon the restricted area, and/or competing, officiating 
  in, observing, working for, or for any purposes participating in the EVENT(S).
. . . 
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  HEREBY ASSUMES FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR AND RISK OF 
  BODILY INJURY, DEATH OR PROPERTY DAMAGES DUE TO THE NEGLIGENCE OR GROSS NEGLIGENCE 
  OF â€œRELEASEESâ€ OR OTHERWISE while in or upon the restricted areas . . . .Â  
EACH OF THE UNDERSIGNED expressly acknowledges and agrees 
  that the activities of the EVENT(S) are very dangerous and involve risk of serious 
  injury and/or death . . . . EACH OF THE UNDERSIGNED further expressly agrees 
  that the foregoing release, waiver, and indemnity agreement is intended to be 
  as broad and inclusive as is permitted by the law of the Province or State in 
  which the EVENT(S) is conducted . . . . 

During a race on the day of the accident, two racecars 
  crashed on the racing surface and Fisherâ€™s wrecker responded to retrieve one 
  of the vehicles.Â  Fisher was riding on the back of a wrecker driven by Stevens 
  and owned by Poindexter.Â  After briefly slowing down to ask if the driver of 
  the first car needed assistance, the wrecker moved off towards the second car.Â  
  Fisher fell off the wrecker, suffering severe head injuries.Â  
Fisher brought suit alleging negligence, gross negligence, 
  and recklessness.Â  Stevens, Poindexter, and Speedway asserted the release as 
  an affirmative defense.Â  All parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, 
  asking for a determination of whether the release acted as complete bar to Fisherâ€™s 
  claims.Â  The trial court granted partial summary judgment to Fisher against 
  Stevens and Poindexter, finding the release, as a matter of law, does not bar 
  Fisherâ€™s claims.Â  The court denied summary judgment to Speedway, finding an 
  issue of fact existed concerning whether Fisher was an employee of the Speedway, 
  thus invalidating the release as being contrary to public policy.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 
  410 S.E.2d 537 (1991).Â  Summary judgment is proper when â€œthere is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and . . . the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable 
  issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably 
  drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.â€Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 
  61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Partial 
  Grant of Summary Judgment
Stevens and Poindexter argue the trial 
  court erred in granting summary judgment to Fisher and finding the Release inapplicable 
  to them as a matter of law.Â  Stevens and Poindexter contend the Release applies 
  to them pursuant to the language releasing â€œVEHICLE OWNERS, DRIVERS, [and] . 
  . . ANY PERSONS IN ANY RESTRICTED AREAâ€ from any liability.Â  
Our Supreme Court, in recognition of the 
  freedom of private parties to contract as they choose, previously has upheld 
  exculpatory contracts such as the one in this case.Â  Huckaby v. Confederate 
  Motor Speedway, Inc., 276 S.C. 629, 281 S.E.2d 223 (1981); Pride v. Southern 
  Bell Tel. & Tel. Co., 244 S.C. 615, 138 S.E.2d 155 (1964).Â  In Huckaby, 
  the Court addressed a waiver and release form in the context of a racetrack 
  and held a waiver agreement voluntarily entered into by a racecar driver barred 
  his cause of action for negligence against the defendant speedway.Â  Huckaby, 
  276 S.C. at 630, 281 S.E.2d at 224.Â  The Court noted several jurisdictions have 
  upheld the validity of releases from liability for injuries arising in connection 
  with automobile racing against public policy challenges to their enforcement.Â  
  Id.Â  
However, notwithstanding the general acceptance 
  of exculpatory contracts, â€œ[s]ince such provisions tend to induce a want of 
  care, they are not favored by the law and will be strictly construed against 
  the party relying thereon.â€Â  Pride, 244 S.C. at 619, 138 S.E.2d at 157.Â  


Common sense and good faith are the leading touchstones of 
  the construction of a contract and contracts are to be so construed as to avoid 
  an absurd result.Â  Where one construction would make a contract unusual or extraordinary 
  and another, equally consistent, would make the contract reasonable, fair and 
  just, the latter construction will prevail.Â Â  

Georgetown Mfg. & Warehouse Co. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Agric., 301 S.C. 514, 518, 392 S.E.2d 801, 804 (Ct. App. 
  1990).
Stevens and Poindexter first claim they 
  are clearly encompassed within the language of the release since they were the 
  driver and owner, respectively, of the wrecker.Â  However, as the trial court 
  found, the terms â€œvehicle ownerâ€ and â€œdriverâ€ are used in this setting to denote 
  the owner and driver of a competing racecar.Â  The NASCAR rulebook governing 
  events at the Myrtle Beach Motor Speedway includes the terms â€œdriversâ€ and â€œcar 
  ownersâ€ within the definition of a â€œcompetitor.â€ [3] Â  These two terms of art are not used to identify any 
  owner or driver of any vehicle.Â  This provision cannot be construed to 
  exempt Stevens and Poindexter from liability for their negligence â€œâ€˜in the absence 
  of explicit language clearly indicating that such was the intent of the parties.â€™â€Â  
  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Combustion Engâ€™g, Inc., 283 S.C. 
  182, 191, 322 S.E.2d 453, 458 (Ct. App. 1984) (quoting Hill v. Carolina Freight 
  Carriers Corp., 71 S.E.2d 133, 137 (N.C. 1952)); see also Dobratz 
  v. Thomson, 468 N.W.2d 654 (Wis. 1991) (finding an exculpatory contract 
  unenforceable as a matter of law due to its ambiguity and uncertainty and stating 
  the facts and circumstances of the agreement must express the intent of the 
  parties with particularity).Â  Neither the wrecker, nor its owner or driver, 
  was explicitly mentioned in the release.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err 
  in strictly construing the language of the release to apply to only the owner 
  and driver of a competing racecar.Â  
Stevens and Poindexter additionally rely 
  on the phrase in the agreement purporting to release â€œANY PERSONS IN ANY RESTRICTED 
  AREAâ€ from liability.Â  As the trial court found, this phrase is overly broad 
  and its enforcement would offend notions of public policy.Â  
South Carolina courts have not specifically 
  addressed whether an overbroad exculpatory contract contravenes public policy.Â  
  In an analogous case, Murray v. Texas Co., 172 S.C. 399, 174 S.E. 231 
  (1934), our Supreme Court addressed whether an indemnity provision relieved 
  a defendant from liability for its own negligence.Â  The Court found the following 
  provision to be broad and comprehensive, yet provocative of some doubt:Â  â€œThe 
  agent shall . . . exonerate the Company and hold it harmless from all claims, 
  suits, and liabilities of every character whatsoever and howsoever arising from 
  the existence or use of the equipment at said station.â€Â  Id. at 401-02, 
  174 S.E. at 231-32.Â  Resolving all doubt in favor of the plaintiff, the Court 
  found the parties did not intend for the contract to relieve the defendant from 
  all liability for its own negligence since it could have plainly stated such 
  if that was the intention of the parties.Â  Id. at 402-03, 174 S.E. at 
  232.Â  Thus, in Murray, the Court resolved the issue on a contractual 
  basis, rather than on public policy grounds.Â  See also Fed. Pac. Elec. 
  v. Carolina Prod. Enters., 298 S.C. 23, 28-29, 378 S.E.2d 56, 58-59 (Ct. 
  App. 1989) (finding a broad, comprehensive indemnity provision to be nonetheless 
  provocative of some doubt concerning its application, thus resolving doubt in 
  favor of party against whom enforcement is sought).
In Richards v. Richards, 513 N.W.2d 
  118 (Wis. 1994), the court found an overly broad exculpatory contract void because 
  it was against public policy.Â  In Richards, a truck driverâ€™s employer 
  required the driverâ€™s wife to sign a â€œPassenger Authorizationâ€ form before she 
  could accompany her husband.Â  The language of the form purported to relieve 
  the employer and â€œall affiliated, associated, or subsidiary companies, partnerships, 
  individuals, or corporations, and all other persons, firms, or corporationsâ€ 
  from any and all liability for harm to the person signing the form.Â  Id. 
  at 119-122.Â  In holding this provision overly broad and in contravention of 
  public policy, the court noted the â€œvery breadth of the release raises questions 
  about its meaning . . . .â€Â  Id. at 122.Â Â Â  
If we agreed with Stevens and Poindexter, the language 
  of the release in the present case would release from liability any person in 
  the restricted area of the track, whether authorized to be there or not.Â  Any 
  person who somehow gained unauthorized access to the restricted area would then 
  be released from liability under this provision.Â  â€œAn exculpatory agreement 
  will be held to contravene public policy if it is so broad â€˜that it would absolve 
  [the defendant] from any injury to the [plaintiff] for any reason.â€™â€Â  Id. 
  at 121 (quoting College Mobile Home Park & Sales, Inc. v. Hoffmann, 
  241 N.W.2d 174, 178 (Wis. 1976)).Â  In Richards, like the present case, 


the release does not refer to an injury the plaintiff may 
  sustain while riding as a passenger in the specified . . . vehicle . . . [and] 
  purports to release the [defendant] from liability for any and all injury to 
  the plaintiff while the plaintiff is a passenger in any vehicle (not 
  necessarily one owned by the [defendant]) at any time . . . .

Richards, 513 N.W.2d at 122 (emphasis added).
Â 
Accordingly, this provision is too broad 
  to be enforceable against Fisher and is void as against public policy.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Moreover, strictly construing this broad provision 
  and resolving any doubt in favor of Fisher, it was not the intent of the parties 
  to give the contract the effect claimed by Stevens and Poindexter, given the 
  release could have plainly stated that Fisher agreed to relieve the wreckerâ€™s 
  owner and driver from all liability.Â  See Murray, 172 S.C. at 
  402-03, 174 S.E. at 232.Â  The contract did not clearly inform Fisher he would 
  be waiving all claims due to Stevensâ€™s and Poindexterâ€™s negligence.Â  See 
  Yauger v. Skiing Enters., Inc., 557 N.W.2d 60 (Wis. 1996) (finding an 
  exculpatory contract void as against public policy because it did not clearly 
  inform the plaintiff he was waiving all claims due to defendantâ€™s negligence).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The cases cited by Stevens and Poindexter 
  are distinguishable from the present case.Â  In each case, the plaintiff sued 
  the track owners, operators, promoters, or sanctioning body, all of whom are 
  parties clearly intended to be covered under waiver and release forms similar 
  to the one in this case. [4] Â  Moreover, none of the cases cited exempted 
  a defendant from liability based on the broad â€œcatch-allâ€ phrase relied on by 
  Stevens and Poindexter.Â  
The trial judge correctly determined the 
  Release did not bar Fisher from recovering against Poindexter and Stevens.Â  
  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s partial grant of summary judgment.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Denial of 
  Speedwayâ€™s Motion for Summary Judgment
Speedway argues the trial court erred 
  in finding the release did not bar Fisherâ€™s claims as a matter of law.Â  The 
  trial court denied Speedwayâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding a genuine 
  issue of material fact concerning whether a master/servant relationship existed 
  between Fisher and Speedway.Â  
We decline to address the merits of this issue.Â  
  The denial of a motion for summary judgment is not directly appealable, even 
  after final judgment.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., Op. 
  No. 25632 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Apr. 28, 2003) (Shearouse Ad. Sh. No. 16 at 24); 
  Ballenger v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 476, 443 S.E.2d 379 (1994).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis, the trial courtâ€™s 
  partial grant of summary judgment to Fisher is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J. and STILWELL, J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  David Fisher, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Daniel 
    Adam Fisher, Sr., has been substituted as Respondent because of the death 
    of Daniel Fisher during the pendency of this appeal.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The trial court also granted National Association for Stock Car 
    Auto Racingâ€™s (NASCAR) motion for summary judgment.Â  Fisher does not appeal 
    this ruling.

 
   
    [3] Â Â  The Myrtle Beach Motor Speedway operates under a NASCAR sanctioning 
    agreement.Â  The sanctioning agreement provides racing events held at the Speedway 
    shall be conducted in accordance with the NASCAR rulebook. 

 
   
    [4] Â Â  See, e.g., Dunn v. Paducah Intâ€™l Raceway, 599 F. 
    Supp. 612 (W.D. Ky. 1984); Rhea v. Horn-Keen Corp., 582 F. Supp. 687 
    (W.D. Va. 1984); LaFrenz v. Lake County Fair Bd., 360 N.E.2d 605 (Ind. 
    Ct. App. 1977); Holzer v. Dakota Speedway, Inc., 610 N.W.2d 787 (S.D. 
    2000); Huber v. Hovey, 501 N.W.2d 53 (Iowa 1993); Plant v. Wilbur, 
    47 S.W.3d 889 (Ark. 2001); Seymour v. New Bremen Speedway, Inc., 287 
    N.E.2d 111 (Ohio Ct. App. 1971); Dean v. MacDonald, 786 A.2d 834 (N.H. 
    2001).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Dedric Thomason, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3666
Heard April 9, 2003 â€“ Filed July 21, 
  2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Appellate Defender Daniel T. Stacey, of SC Office of 
  Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Duane Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.: Dedric Thomason pled guilty 
  to two counts of resisting arrest in violation of South Carolina Code Annotated 
  section 16-9-320 (Supp. 2001).Â  During sentencing, Thomason moved to withdraw 
  his guilty pleas, and the circuit court denied his motion.Â  On appeal, Thomason 
  contends the circuit court erred by refusing his request to withdraw his pleas 
  because the state failed to abide by a plea agreement.Â  Additionally, Thomason 
  argues we should reverse his sentences because they resulted from the courtâ€™s 
  bias and prejudice.Â  We affirm.Â 
FACTS
A Greenville County grand jury returned a two-count 
  indictment against Thomason.Â  Each count charged him with resisting arrest involving 
  an assault on a law enforcement officer in violation of section 16-9-320(B).Â  
  Thomason pled guilty to one count, and on the remaining count, he pled to the 
  lesser-included offense of resisting arrest under section 16-9-320(A).Â  Neither 
  Thomason nor the state advised the circuit court of any plea negotiations or 
  agreement.Â  The state recommended probation.Â  Â Â 
The circuit court questioned Thomason to determine 
  if he understood the nature of the offenses, the possible punishments, and the 
  rights he would be waiving.Â  Thomason confirmed no promises had been made to 
  induce his guilty pleas.Â  During this questioning, neither the state nor Thomasonâ€™s 
  attorney alerted the circuit court to any plea agreement.
Having determined Thomasonâ€™s pleas were knowingly, 
  intelligently, and voluntarily entered, the circuit court accepted them, stating:Â  
  â€œAll right.Â  Iâ€™ll accept his plea if the State gives me a substantial factual 
  basis for it.â€Â  The state then presented a limited summary of the facts and 
  recommended probation.Â  Thomason did not argue the summary was legally insufficient 
  to support the charges.Â  
Hearing the recommendation of probation, the circuit 
  court immediately advised Thomason, his attorney, and the state, the circuit 
  court was not bound by any recommendation and would be the sole judge of the 
  sentences to be imposed.Â  Thomasonâ€™s attorney acknowledged this fact and did 
  not mention a plea agreement to the circuit court.Â  
Thomasonâ€™s attorney then gave a factual presentation 
  in mitigation of the offenses, shifting blame for the incident to the arresting 
  law enforcement officers.Â  Hearing this, the circuit court asked if the solicitor 
  notified the officers regarding the pleas and the recommendation of probation.Â  
  When the solicitor could not confirm the officers had been notified, the circuit 
  court recessed the hearing and summoned the officers to appear. 
  [1] Â  
Thomason then moved to withdraw his guilty pleas, arguing, 
  for the first time, he had a plea agreement with the state limiting the stateâ€™s 
  factual presentation.Â  Thomason claimed allowing the officers to present controverted 
  facts would violate the plea agreement to his prejudice because he could not 
  contest their version of events in a guilty plea as he could through cross-examination 
  in a trial.Â  
Â  The circuit court refused to allow Thomason to 
  withdraw his pleas and resumed the sentencing when one of the two officers appeared.Â  
  As Thomason feared, the officer presented facts adverse to Thomason and confirmed 
  he had not been notified of the guilty pleas or the solicitorâ€™s proposed recommendation 
  of probation.Â  
Following the officerâ€™s presentation, Thomason 
  again moved to withdraw his pleas.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, opining 
  Thomasonâ€™s attorney and the state had misled the circuit court in the factual 
  presentation.Â  The circuit court rejected the recommendation of probation and 
  sentenced Thomason to one-year imprisonment for resisting arrest under subsection 
  (A) and six years imprisonment for resisting arrest with assault under subsection 
  (B).Â  Thomason appeals.
ISSUES PRESENTED

  
    
      I.     
   
      Was Thomason entitled to withdraw his guilty pleas as a matter of right 
  before the circuit court imposed sentence? 
   
    
    
      II.  
   
      Did the circuit court abuse its discretion in refusing to allow Thomason 
  to withdraw his guilty pleas based on the stateâ€™s breach of a plea agreement? 
   
    
    
      III.    
   
      Was Thomasonâ€™s sentence a result of the circuit courtâ€™s bias and prejudice 
  resulting from anger at Thomasonâ€™s counsel? 
   
    
  

 LAW/ANALYSIS 
   

  
    
      I.   
       Was Thomason entitled to withdraw his guilty 
  pleas as a matter of right before the circuit court imposed sentence?
    
  

Thomason argues he was entitled to withdraw his guilty pleas 
  as a matter of right.Â  We disagree.Â 
â€œAll that is required before a plea can be accepted is that 
  the defendant understand the nature and crucial elements of the charges, the 
  consequences of the plea, and the constitutional rights he is waiving, and that 
  the record reflect a factual basis for the plea.â€Â  Rollison v. State, 
  346 S.C. 506, 511, 552 S.E.2d 290, 292 (2001).
A guilty plea may not be accepted unless it is voluntarily 
  and understandingly made.Â  Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 242 (1969); 
  State v. Lambert, 266 S.C. 574, 577-78, 225 S.E.2d 340, 341-42 (1976).Â  
  However, once a defendant enters a guilty plea, whether to allow withdrawal 
  of the plea is left to the sound discretion of the circuit court.Â  State 
  v. Riddle, 278 S.C. 148, 150, 292 S.E.2d 795, 796 (1982).
Thomason acknowledged he was guilty of the charges 
  and was voluntarily pleading guilty.Â  The circuit court questioned him to determine 
  whether the pleas were knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently entered. At 
  that stage, the circuit court stated it accepted the pleas pending presentation 
  of the facts by the state.Â  Thomason did not then move to withdraw his pleas.Â  
  Next, the state presented facts legally sufficient to support the charges and 
  recommended probation.Â  Again, Thomason did not move to withdraw the pleas and 
  raised no objection to the sufficiency of the factual presentation given by 
  the state.Â  Thomason then began to discuss sentencing issues with the court.Â  
  Under the authority of State v. Cantrell, 250 S.C. 376, 158 S.E.2d 189 
  (1967), and State v. Barton,Â  325 S.C. 522, 481 S.E.2d 439 (Ct. App. 
  1997), we conclude the circuit court accepted Thomasonâ€™s guilty pleas and whether 
  to allow withdrawal rested within the sound discretion of the circuit court.
In Cantrell, a case factually similar to this case, 
  the defendant entered guilty pleas, which the circuit court accepted.Â  During 
  the preliminary stages of sentencing, the circuit court began to review the 
  defendantâ€™s prior statement to police.Â  In the statement, the defendant admitted 
  multiple prior offenses.Â  Based on this information, the circuit court indicated 
  it was not inclined to give a probationary sentence, whereupon the defendant 
  moved to withdraw his plea.Â  250 S.C. at 378, 158 S.E.2d at 190-91.
Upholding the trial courtâ€™s decision to deny the motion to 
  withdraw the pleas, the supreme court noted a guilty plea â€œis a confession of 
  guilt made in a formal manner and is equivalent to and as binding as a conviction 
  after a trial on the merits.Â  It has the same effect in law as a verdict of 
  guilt and authorizes the imposition of the punishment prescribed by law.â€Â  Cantrell, 
  250 S.C. at 379, 158 S.E.2d at 191.Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]n accused is not permitted 
  to speculate on the supposed clemency of the judge and enter a plea of guilty 
  with the right to retract it if he finds that his expectation was not realized.â€ 
  Id. at 380, 158 S.E.2d at 192-93.Â  Thus, under those circumstances, our 
  supreme court ruled the decision to deny withdrawal of the plea rested within 
  the sound discretion of the circuit court.Â  
In Barton, the defendant entered his guilty pleas, 
  and the circuit court began to impose sentence.Â  Before the circuit court could 
  complete the publication of its sentence, Barton interrupted.Â  In a later motion 
  for reconsideration, Barton claimed he interrupted to withdraw his guilty pleas.Â  
  Under those circumstances, this Court ruled the guilty pleas were entered, and 
  the proceeding entered the sentencing phase at the time of Bartonâ€™s interruption.Â  
  Therefore, refusal to allow withdrawal of the accepted pleas was limited to 
  review for abuse of discretion.Â  Id. at 525-28, 481 S.E.2d at 441-42.
Based on this record, we conclude the guilty pleas in this 
  case were clearly accepted by the circuit court.Â  Thus, once the state completed 
  its recitation of the facts, the hearing entered the sentencing phase, and no 
  further ruling was required to accept the guilty pleas.Â  See Boykin, 
  395 U.S. at 242; Rollison, 346 S.C. at 511, 552 S.E.2d at 292; Cantrell, 
  250 S.C. at 380, 158 S.E.2d at 191; Barton, 325 S.C. at 531, 481 S.E.2d 
  at 443-44.Â  Therefore, whether to allow Thomason to withdraw his guilty pleas 
  was a matter resting within the sound discretion of the circuit court, and Thomason 
  could not withdraw his pleas as a matter of right.Â  See Riddle, 
  278 S.C. at 150, 292 S.E.2d at 796.

  
    
      II. 
       Did the circuit court abuse its discretion in 
  refusing to allow Thomason to withdraw his guilty pleas based on the stateâ€™s 
  breach of a plea agreement?
    
  

Thomason argues he was entitled to withdraw his guilty 
  pleas because the state breached the terms of a plea agreement.Â  Thomason contends 
  the plea agreement required the state to notify the officers and ensure their 
  accord with the stateâ€™s factual presentation and proposed disposition.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the circuit court may conduct 
  an inquiry broad in scope, largely unlimited either as to the kind of information 
  it may consider or the source from which the information may come, to assist 
  it in determining the sentence to be imposed.Â  State v. Gulledge, 326 
  S.C. 220, 228, 487 S.E.2d 590, 594 (1997); Cantrell, 250 S.C. at 380, 
  158 S.E.2d at 191 (holding when sentencing a convicted defendant, a circuit 
  court exercises a wide discretion regarding the sources and types of evidence 
  it may use to assist it in determining the kind and extent of punishment to 
  be imposed).Â  As noted in Gulledge, â€œ[i]n a sentencing proceeding, evidentiary 
  rules are inapplicable[,]â€ and the court may consider inadmissible evidence, 
  so long as the information is relevant, reliable and trustworthy.Â  326 S.C. 
  at 228, 487 S.E.2d at 594.
Furthermore, the circuit courtâ€™s inquiry into notification 
  of the victims is appropriate, as is providing an opportunity for the victims 
  to be heard during sentencing.Â  See S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 24. 
Thomason argues the state agreed to limit the factual 
  presentation to those statements contained in the solicitorâ€™s factual presentation.Â  
  Thus, Thomason contends allowing the officer to present his version of the events 
  violated the plea agreement and prejudiced him by limiting his ability to cross-examine 
  the witnesses.Â  However, no such plea agreement was divulged to the court prior 
  to the acceptance of the guilty pleas.Â Â Â Â  
Our supreme court has recognized a plea agreement rests 
  on contractual principles.Â  State v. Gates, 299 S.C. 92, 94-95, 382 S.E.2d 
  886-87 (1989); see also Santobello v. New York, 404 U.S. 257, 
  262 (1971) (â€œ[W]hen a plea rests in any significant degree on a promise or agreement 
  of the prosecutor . . . such promise must be fulfilled.â€); Alston v. State, 
  379 A.2d 754, 757 (Md. 1978) (â€œWhen the Stateâ€™s Attorney has given his word 
  in the form of a plea bargain and that bargain is accepted by the trial court, 
  it behooves the Stateâ€™s Attorney to make every reasonable effort to correct 
  any deviation from the bargain when the deviation is called to his attention.â€).Â  

However, plea agreements will only be reviewed when 
  they are clearly delineated on the record.Â  In Thrift, our supreme court 
  ruled:

Today, the complexity of cases dictates that a reliable 
  record exist containing the specific terms of any plea agreement.Â  We hold, 
  therefore, that effective with this decision, all plea agreements must be on 
  the record and must recite the scope, offenses, and individuals involved in 
  the agreement.Â  We also hold that prospectively for all plea agreements entered 
  after the filing of this opinion, we will limit our review of a plea agreement 
  only to those terms which are fully set forth in the record . . . .Â  [Furthermore,] 
  neither the State nor the defendant will be able to enforce plea agreement terms 
  which do not appear on the record before the trial judge who accepts the plea.Â  


312 S.C. at 295-96, 440 S.E.2d at 348-49. 
In this case, there was no written plea agreement in 
  the record, and neither party identified an oral plea agreement meeting the 
  requirements of Thrift prior to the circuit courtâ€™s acceptance of Thomasonâ€™s 
  pleas.Â  Only after the circuit court accepted the pleas and undertook its duty 
  to examine all of the pertinent facts necessary to fashion an appropriate sentence 
  did Thomason assert, for the first time, there was a plea agreement limiting 
  the factual presentation.
Under these circumstances, we conclude Thomasonâ€™s assertion 
  was untimely and did not comply with Thrift.Â  Consequently, we cannot 
  review the alleged plea agreement.Â  
In so holding, we acknowledge our supreme court has 
  placed an affirmative, shared duty on circuit court judges and counsel to ensure 
  the scope of plea agreements is sufficiently entered on the record.Â  Thrift, 
  312 S.C. at 296, 440 S.E.2d at 349.Â  However, in this case, neither the state 
  nor Thomason alerted the circuit court to any plea agreement specifically limiting 
  the factual presentation given by the state.Â  Under these circumstances, the 
  circuit court fulfilled its duty under Thrift by inquiring, prior to 
  the acceptance of the pleas, whether any promises had been made to Thomason 
  in exchange for his guilty pleas.Â  
Furthermore, Thomasonâ€™s argument that he was prejudiced 
  by his inability to cross-examine the witnesses is unavailing because he waived 
  his right to cross-examination of the witnesses when he knowingly, voluntarily, 
  and intelligently entered his guilty pleas. See Gulledge, 326 
  S.C. at 228, 487 S.E.2d at 594.Â  As noted in Gulledge, the only constraint 
  on the information which may be considered by the circuit court at sentencing 
  is that it be relevant and have sufficient indicia of reliability.Â  Id.
Having failed to present an enforceable plea agreement, 
  Thomason argues no other basis for his claim the circuit court abused its discretion. 
  Â Consequently, we hold there was no abuse.Â  

  
    III.   
     Was Thomasonâ€™s sentence a result of the courtâ€™s 
  bias and prejudice resulting from anger at Thomasonâ€™s counsel?
  

Thomason argues the circuit court was biased and prejudiced 
  against him because the circuit court was angry with his attorney.Â  
During sentencing, Thomasonâ€™s attorney twice assured the 
  circuit court the solicitor had communicated with the arresting officers about 
  the guilty pleas.Â  Thomasonâ€™s attorney then clarified he believed the solicitor 
  had contacted the officers as a part of plea negotiations.Â  However, when the 
  arresting officer later appeared and denied any knowledge of the guilty pleas 
  or the sentence recommendation, the circuit court opined Thomasonâ€™s attorney 
  and the solicitor misled it.
On appeal, Thomason argues this exchange, coupled with the 
  lengthy sentence of incarceration, proves the severity of the sentences resulted 
  from the circuit courtâ€™s bias and prejudice.Â  We conclude this argument is not 
  preserved for appeal.
â€œGenerally, where bias and prejudice of a trial judge is 
  claimed, the issue must be raised when the facts first become known and, in 
  any event, before the matter is submitted for decision.â€Â  Butler v. Sea Pines 
  Plantation Co., 282 S.C. 113, 122-123, 317 S.E.2d 464, 470 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
  For an appellate court to review an issue, a contemporaneous objection at the 
  trial level is required. State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 
  869, 873 (1994). â€œ[A]n objection should be sufficiently specific to bring into 
  focus the precise nature of the alleged error so it can be reasonably understood 
  by the trial judge.â€ State v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 411, 548 S.E.2d 
  213, 216 (2001).Â  Moreover, a party cannot argue one theory at trial and a different 
  theory on appeal.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 
  (1989).
Thomason made no motion for recusal. Further, he neither 
  objected to the sentence nor moved the circuit court to alter or amend the judgment.Â  
  Thus, this argument is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Hoffman, 
  312 S.C. at 393, 440 S.E.2d at 873; Prioleau, 345 S.C. at 411, 548 S.E.2d 
  at 216; Bailey, 298 S.C. at 5, 377 S.E.2d at 584; see also 
  State v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 462, 510 S.E.2d 423, 424 (1999) (holding 
  an objection to sentence exceeding the maximum allowable by law does not raise 
  a question of subject matter jurisdiction and cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal).Â  
We recognize there is authority relaxing this rule where 
  the tone and tenor of the trial judgeâ€™s remarks are such that any objection 
  would have been futile. State v. Pace, 316 S.C. 71, 74, 447 S.E.2d 186, 
  187 (1994).Â  However, the record in this case does not support such a conclusion.
The circuit court explained its policy to listen 
  to the facts before sentencing and emphasized sentencing was exclusively within 
  the purview of the circuit court.Â  The circuit court gave Thomason an opportunity 
  to respond to the officerâ€™s statements and made sure the additional facts had 
  been given to Thomason during discovery.
Contrary to Thomasonâ€™s assertion that there is 
  no other explanation for the harsher sentences imposed, the facts revealed by 
  the law enforcement officer were more egregious than the limited version of 
  events conveyed by the solicitor. [2] Â  Further, the sentences imposed by the circuit 
  court were within the range allowed by law.
Throughout the sentencing proceeding, the circuit 
  court remained focused on the facts pertinent to sentencing, responding with 
  an appropriate and well-reasoned ruling to each argument raised by counsel.Â  
  The record simply does not reasonably lend itself to the conclusion a timely 
  objection would have been futile.Â  Thus, notwithstanding the circuit courtâ€™s 
  disappointment in the handling of the matter by counsel, we conclude this issue 
  was not raised to the circuit court and is not preserved for review.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Thomasonâ€™s sentences are
AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL, J., and STROM, Acting Judge, 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  The solicitor who presented the case was substituting for the solicitor 
    assigned to handle the case. 

 
   
    [2]  The officerâ€™s version revealed he and his partner were called to 
    the scene because Thomason was shooting a firearm outside a residence.Â  The 
    officer testified Thomason repeatedly ordered his pit bull dog to attack the 
    officers as they tried to arrest him.Â  The dog did attack one of the two officers, 
    diverting his attention from the arrest.Â  The remaining officer fell to the 
    ground with Thomason on top of him.
